story:
May 19, 2015 - We're down to the last few hours of this campaign, and we're SO CLOSE to having it 200% funded--my mind is STILL spinning from how quickly we hit 100% just four days after it started. Let's make the last day an awesome one, and hit the big $10,000! Many thanks to everyone who backs this campaign :D
Stretch Goal Updates!
May 14, 2015 - WOOHOO!!! We hit $9000 last night! THANK YOU!!!! That means I will be offering a free Livestream class to campaign backers after the deck and book have been sent out. Now--let's see if we can get to $12,000 and get that audio book stretch goal unlocked!

April 20, 2015 - Hey, all! So we hit $7,000 (actually $7,030) this morning on the official Tarot of Bones IndieGoGo campaign, just two weeks after it went live--woohoo, and THANK YOU!!!!!! This means that we're now over 140% funded, AND we've reached the first stretch goal, and I will be adding a Happy Squirrel card to the official Tarot of Bones deck. 

I'd also like to announce the next two stretch goals:

If this IndieGoGo campaign reaches $9,000 before it ends, once the Tarot of Bones deck and book are out, I will offer a free Livestream class on how to use the Tarot of Bones exclusively for IndieGoGo backers. For those who can't make it, I will email the video to you afterward, and I will wait a month before I put it up on YouTube for everyone to see. This will happen in the latter half of 2016 (unless for some unknown reason I have to release the deck and book later than Summer 2016). 

And if the campaign reaches $12,000 before it ends, I will record an audiobook version of the Tarot of Bones book! This will be useful not just for people who are better audio learners than readers, but also for people who may have limited vision. I will be recording it at home, so this will not be a pro-level audiobook, but I promise to do the very best that I can with freeware like Audacity. I plan for the audiobook to be released within a year as both a downloadable file and a CD after the hardcopy deck and book are out. All IndieGoGo backers will get the file version of the audiobook for free.

13 April , 2015 - Can you believe it? We funded this thing in its first 100 hours!   Thank you, thank you, thank you to everyone who chipped in, whether by backing the campaign or spreading the word or being moral support through this crazy week. So now that we've got our first $5,000 (and change) what's next? This:

Allow me to announce our first stretch goal: If the Tarot of Bones IndieGoGo campaign gets to $7000 before it ends, I will add a Happy Squirrel card to the official Tarot of Bones deck and book. What's the Happy Squirrel card? It's something of an in-joke among tarot fans, stemming from a 1995 episode of The Simpsons. Here's more of an explanation.
The $5000 already covers my materials for the assemblages, with a little left over to put toward printing/shipping, perk fulfillment and other administrative costsIf we get to $7000, I will have more administrative funding, and I'll make a Happy Squirrel assemblage piece to be included as the 79th card in the deck. We're already at a little over $5700--let's see how fast you can make me have to come up with the next stretch goal!

Bringing the Tarot of Bones to Life!

My name is Lupa; I am an author, artist and amateur naturalist living in Portland, OR. I have been pagan since 1996, and started reading tarot and other divination systems shortly thereafter. In 1998 I began incorporating animal hides and bones and other natural items in my artwork and spirituality, and caring for these sacred remains became central to my life. I've written several books on nature spirituality, among them Skin Spirits: The Spiritual and Magical Use of Animal Parts (Megalithica Books, 2010) and Plant and Fungus Totems: Connect With Spirits of Field, Forest and Garden (Llewellyn, 2015). I have been self-employed full-time since 2011 and am the breadwinner of my household, though I make time to go visit my beloved Oregon wilderness which inspires so many of my works.

(Note - this is a mockup; final card may look different.)

Now I'm bringing together the threads of my creative career in an ambitious project: The Tarot of Bones. This deck and book set combines the nature-inspired symbolism of animal bones with the tarot's well-loved archetypes to create an unparalleled divination set for the 21st century. For each of the 78 cards I am creating permanent assemblage artworks featuring carefully chosen and legally acquired animal bones and other natural materials reflecting the cards' messages. High-quality photos of these pieces will be used for the card art. The full-length companion book, available both in paperback and ebook form, will explore the symbolism of the cards in detail and my inspiration in creating each.

While I have been professionally published multiple times over, this is an intensely personal project, and I have opted to self-publish the Tarot of Bones. My goal is to have all 78 assemblage pieces completed by the end of 2015, and to publish the deck and book in Summer 2016. I've already made a lot of progress and acquired many of the materials I need to keep going, You can help me achieve my goals with this project by backing me here on IndieGoGo!

Get the Deck, Book, and More!

So what sorts of goodies can you get by backing this campaign? Here are a few possibilities for you to choose from:

  • The Tarot of Bones Deck (with the companion paperback or ebook)
  • Prints of select cards, approximately 8" x 10" in size
  • A hand-sewn (by me!) leather bag to keep your deck in
  • Original assemblage pieces used in the making of the Tarot of Bones
  • A one of a kind, custom-made assemblage piece made to your specifications
  • Copies of my other books, your choice of which one(s)
  • A special thank you in the Tarot of Bones companion book and on the official website

If you can't decide which one you reallllly want, keep in mind you can claim multiple perks by making bigger and/or multiple contributions--more information here.

Also, please remember that perk amounts include my costs for materials for fulfilling and shipping them, and also account for IndieGoGo and Paypal taking out their fees!

Now for a little more detail on some of these perks:


Prints: I'll be creating prints of three of my favorite cards to date: Justice (above), Magician (the piece shown in the mock-up card above) and the Ace of Pentacles (shown under the Timelines, Risks and Challenges heading below); you'll get your pick of one of these, or a collection of all three. The photos shown on this campaign are just to show the work; the photos used for the prints will be the same ones used for the final card art, and therefore the prints will be printed at the same time as the cards so all can be delivered at once in Summer 2016.


Leather Pouch: Leather pouches were one of the first projects I learned to make when I initially started working with hides and bones. You can choose to claim a deck with a leather pouch made just the right size for it. US folks will get one made of deerskin; international folks will get cowhide due to customs restrictions. Pouches will be shipped when the decks are shipped in Summer 2016.

Original Tarot of Bones Assemblage Piece: There are three different options for people in the U.S. who want to buy one of the original assemblage pieces used in making the Tarot of Bones. There is an additional option for international buyers to get one of a very limited number of the assemblage pieces that do not include wildlife or plant parts and can therefore be sent out of the U.S. While I will ultimately choose who gets which piece, you are welcome to contact me with your five favorites at the end of 2016 once all the assemblages are completed. Also, as I will be displaying some of these originals at galleries and other art venues in the latter half of 2016, they will not be delivered to their new homes until sometime in 2017. (You will get your deck and book set plus the three prints in Summer 2016.)

Note: This is not one of the assemblages for the Tarot of Bones. It's Flora et Fauna II, a piece I did in 2014.

Custom Assemblage Piece: A very limited number of backers can opt to get a custom assemblage piece made by me, in addition to one of the originals from the Tarot of Bones. You can look at my portfolio to get some idea of the work that I do. Please keep in mind that the laws governing your location may limit the materials I'm allowed to work with for your piece; some substitutions, such as resin skulls, may be available. (You will get your deck and book set plus the three prints in Summer 2016.)

Books: I've written and published several books prior to this project. You can choose to bring home one or more of these titles, shipped along with your Tarot of Bones set in Summer 2016:

Fang and Fur, Blood and Bone: A Primal Guide to Animal Magic

DIY Totemism: Your Personal Guide to Animal Totems

Skin Spirits: The Spiritual and Magical Uses of Animal Parts

New Paths to Animal Totems: Three Alternative Approaches to Creating Your Own Totemism

Plant and Fungus Totems: Connect With Spirits of Field, Forest and Garden

And you can even preorder my next book, due out January 2016 from Llewellyn Worldwide (your copy will be shipped with your Tarot of Bones set in Summer 2016):

Nature Spirituality From the Ground Up: Connect With Totems in Your Bioregion

Please note that my anthologies are not included in this special offer. 

$howing You the Money

The Tarot of Bones is a very resource-intensive project, both in terms of materials and time invested. To date I have already put around $1500 of my own money into the skulls, bones and other materials for the 78 permanent assemblage pieces, and will continue to invest funds into materials, printing, shipping and related costs. 

While the money I've already spent has covered a significant amount of what I'll need, I still need to purchase more materials in order to complete the assemblages. The skulls (and in some cases high-quality, handmade skull replicas) are the most expensive components. Most of them are high-quality collectibles, many cannot be found secondhand except on very rare occasion, and some are quite expensive even at wholesale prices. 

I've mitigated the costs some by making most of the other materials secondhand, haunting thrift stores and yard sales in Portland and beyond for old cutting boards, half-full tubes of acrylic paint and other salvaged art supplies. I collect a lot of the plant material and other natural materials myself, to include when walking around my Portland neighborhood. I am seeking secondhand skulls and bones from private collections when I'm able, and when I do buy new I often buy directly from the individuals and small businesses who reclaim and clean these bones. However, I'm still making almost eighty individual assemblage pieces--that's a lot of art supplies to bring home!

This is a flexible-funding campaign, which means that if I do not meet my goal, I still get the money (but IndieGoGo gets to keep a much larger percentage of it, 9% as opposed to 4%, not including Paypal's fees on top of that). Even if I don't raise $5,000, I will continue with the project with the goal of having the deck and book released summer 2016; the successful completion of this campaign will make that much easier. Here's where your contributions will go:

If I raise $2,500, after fees I will be able to purchase the most expensive skulls (real and replica) I still need to obtain. Some of these cost a few hundred dollars, a significant amount of money for me to spend at once. I can get these pricier skulls into my studio and breathe a little more easily about the costs.

If I raise $3,500, after fees I'll be able to buy all the remaining materials I need for the assemblage pieces, which will help me stick to my production schedule and possibly beat my deadlines since I'll already have everything I need to make the magic happen! 

My primary goal of $5,000, after fees,will allow me to purchase the rest of the materials I need. It will also help me to fund other costs for this project, ranging from printing and shipping costs for the deck and book, prints and other perks, and compensating myself for time spent collecting materials, taking photos, writing the book manuscript and online updates, and other time invested in this project. While the IndieGoGo campaign is not my sole source of funding for this project, it will allow me to divert a lot less money from my everyday income and help me compensate for the time that I spent working on the Tarot of Bones. In short, by backing this campaign you'll be keeping a roof over my head while I dedicate myself to this great work.

While the majority of costs will go to the production of the set, I will be donating a to-be-decided portion of the proceeds to nonprofit organizations that benefit wildlife and their habitats. I am already a regular contributor to several of these organizations, Xerces Society for Invertebrate Conservation and the Nature Conservancy, including making monthly donations to a select few. While the exact amount I give varies from month to month depending on my income and expenses, I do what I can to help these organizations keep up their good work. 

Timeline, Risks and Challenges

I've published several books and run a yearly arts festival in Portland (Curious Gallery), so I am well acquainted with deadlines and the importance of meeting them. To that end, I've laid out a timeline for production of the Tarot of Bones:

End of 2015 – Deadline for completing all 78 assemblage pieces for the Tarot of Bones. I will be working steadily on these throughout 2015; I have to complete 6 1/2 pieces per month to meet this deadline, and I’m going to try to get out ahead of that, particular once festival season starts in summer.

January 2016 – Send the Tarot of Bones book to an independent editor (I will be self-publishing the book); it will likely go through multiple editing sessions throughout spring.

January – April 2016 – final photographs of art pieces for card art; final card designs

May-June 2016 – Have proofs of the 78 cards and the book ready to send to the printers for approval

June-July 2016 – Publication and release of the first printing of the Tarot of Bones deck and book

I started making assemblage pieces in mid-January. As of April 7, 2015 I have already completed 20 of the 78 assemblage pieces. When I finish creating an assemblage, I write about it in the manuscript for the Tarot of Bones companion book, which is already over 8,000 words long. So in just four months I've made a tremendous amount of progress. Additionally, as I am 100% self-employed I have more time and schedule flexibility than many creative folks, and I've been able to leverage that well so far. 

Time is the scarcest commodity. In addition to working on the Tarot of Bones, I am currently in the editing process for my next book with Llewellyn Worldwide, Nature Spirituality From the Ground Up: Connect With Totems in Your Ecosystem, due out January 2016, and putting details on another manuscript as of yet unclaimed by any publisher. I vend my art and books at several events throughout the Pacific Northwest and am constantly looking for art shows and galleries to submit my assemblage work to. I maintain two blogs, a very busy Etsy shop, and a healthy social media presence. And I try to go hiking once a week to maintain my sanity.

All that being said, this is not a case of if the Tarot of Bones will happen, but when. Barring my unlikely disability or demise, it will happen even if I have to pay more out of pocket for the expenses, and even if it comes out later than anticipated. Your backing will help me stay on schedule, and is greatly appreciated!

Why Is This Important?


The Tarot of Bones is born out of a creative career spanning nearly two decades, embracing both writing and art, and challenging me to excellence not only in familiar media but in new skills as well. At the end of it, I will be able to offer others a valuable tool in divination as well as a beautiful work of art. 

Moreover, it's a reminder that we are still a part of the natural world. I chose bones as the primary material for this project because throughout the entirety of the body of a vertebrate animal–human included–the bones are the strongest portions. They provide a scaffolding on which the rest of the animal is built, and they remain long after flesh and sinew have gone away. Likewise, although generations of people come and go, the desire to connect to something greater than one’s self and to engage one’s intuition endures. Through bones we can speak with our evolutionary ancestors; through divination we create patterns that help us make sense of the world around us–and the worlds within.

Finally, whether you're able to back this campaign or not, please help spread the word! Use the share tools that IndieGoGo provides. Post a link on Facebook, Tumblr, Twitter and elsewhere. Email people you think would be interested. Contact alternative, art and other media sources who may be interested in covering what I'm working on here (I have a press release available if you need it!) The more people who know about this campaign, the merrier--and the stronger the Tarot of Bones will be!

Thank you to all of you for your help,

Lupa

http://www.thetarotofbones.com
story_txt:
May 19, 2015 - We're down to the last few hours of this campaign, and we're SO CLOSE to having it 200% funded--my mind is STILL spinning from how quickly we hit 100% just four days after it started. Let's make the last day an awesome one, and hit the big $10,000! Many thanks to everyone who backs this campaign :D
Stretch Goal Updates!
May 14, 2015 - WOOHOO!!! We hit $9000 last night! THANK YOU!!!! That means I will be offering a free Livestream class to campaign backers after the deck and book have been sent out. Now--let's see if we can get to $12,000 and get that audio book stretch goal unlocked!
April 20, 2015 - Hey, all! So we hit $7,000 (actually $7,030) this morning on the official Tarot of Bones IndieGoGo campaign, just two weeks after it went live--woohoo, and THANK YOU!!!!!! This means that we're now over 140% funded, AND we've reached the first stretch goal, and I will be adding a Happy Squirrel card to the official Tarot of Bones deck. 
I'd also like to announce the next two stretch goals:
If this IndieGoGo campaign reaches $9,000 before it ends, once the Tarot of Bones deck and book are out, I will offer a free Livestream class on how to use the Tarot of Bones exclusively for IndieGoGo backers. For those who can't make it, I will email the video to you afterward, and I will wait a month before I put it up on YouTube for everyone to see. This will happen in the latter half of 2016 (unless for some unknown reason I have to release the deck and book later than Summer 2016). 
And if the campaign reaches $12,000 before it ends, I will record an audiobook version of the Tarot of Bones book! This will be useful not just for people who are better audio learners than readers, but also for people who may have limited vision. I will be recording it at home, so this will not be a pro-level audiobook, but I promise to do the very best that I can with freeware like Audacity. I plan for the audiobook to be released within a year as both a downloadable file and a CD after the hardcopy deck and book are out. All IndieGoGo backers will get the file version of the audiobook for free.
13 April , 2015 - Can you believe it? We funded this thing in its first 100 hours!   Thank you, thank you, thank you to everyone who chipped in, whether by backing the campaign or spreading the word or being moral support through this crazy week. So now that we've got our first $5,000 (and change) what's next? This:
Allow me to announce our first stretch goal: If the Tarot of Bones IndieGoGo campaign gets to $7000 before it ends, I will add a Happy Squirrel card to the official Tarot of Bones deck and book. What's the Happy Squirrel card? It's something of an in-joke among tarot fans, stemming from a 1995 episode of The Simpsons. Here's more of an explanation.

The $5000 already covers my materials for the assemblages, with a little left over to put toward printing/shipping, perk fulfillment and other administrative costsIf we get to $7000, I will have more administrative funding, and I'll make a Happy Squirrel assemblage piece to be included as the 79th card in the deck. We're already at a little over $5700--let's see how fast you can make me have to come up with the next stretch goal!

 

Bringing the Tarot of Bones to Life!

My name is Lupa; I am an author, artist and amateur naturalist living in Portland, OR. I have been pagan since 1996, and started reading tarot and other divination systems shortly thereafter. In 1998 I began incorporating animal hides and bones and other natural items in my artwork and spirituality, and caring for these sacred remains became central to my life. I've written several books on nature spirituality, among them Skin Spirits: The Spiritual and Magical Use of Animal Parts (Megalithica Books, 2010) and Plant and Fungus Totems: Connect With Spirits of Field, Forest and Garden (Llewellyn, 2015). I have been self-employed full-time since 2011 and am the breadwinner of my household, though I make time to go visit my beloved Oregon wilderness which inspires so many of my works.



(Note - this is a mockup; final card may look different.)

Now I'm bringing together the threads of my creative career in an ambitious project: The Tarot of Bones. This deck and book set combines the nature-inspired symbolism of animal bones with the tarot's well-loved archetypes to create an unparalleled divination set for the 21st century. For each of the 78 cards I am creating permanent assemblage artworks featuring carefully chosen and legally acquired animal bones and other natural materials reflecting the cards' messages. High-quality photos of these pieces will be used for the card art. The full-length companion book, available both in paperback and ebook form, will explore the symbolism of the cards in detail and my inspiration in creating each.

While I have been professionally published multiple times over, this is an intensely personal project, and I have opted to self-publish the Tarot of Bones. My goal is to have all 78 assemblage pieces completed by the end of 2015, and to publish the deck and book in Summer 2016. I've already made a lot of progress and acquired many of the materials I need to keep going, You can help me achieve my goals with this project by backing me here on IndieGoGo!

The Tarot of Bones Deck (with the companion paperback or ebook)


Prints of select cards, approximately 8" x 10" in size


A hand-sewn (by me!) leather bag to keep your deck in


Original assemblage pieces used in the making of the Tarot of Bones


A one of a kind, custom-made assemblage piece made to your specifications


Copies of my other books, your choice of which one(s)


A special thank you in the Tarot of Bones companion book and on the official website


If you can't decide which one you reallllly want, keep in mind you can claim multiple perks by making bigger and/or multiple contributions--more information here.

story:
Hi!  My name is David Salazar. I am a metal artist based out of New Orleans, Louisiana. I work in large scale art and small scale art in many mediums but metal fabrication, blacksmithing, and welding are my specialty. I have built and worked on several large scale art projects for The Burning Man Project and Burning Flipside including, Oceanic Anamnesis (The flame shooting unicorn) and The MechaGator. 

My latest project, which will be installed first at Burning Flipside in central Texas, is a study in redundancy and form in art. It asks people to question what art really is and how it can be interpreted. It is meant to be part sculpture, part sound installation, part flame effect and part interactive art that the public will be able to interact with.  

The project will be a 10 foot tall hanging steel Pinata that will be suspended from a sturdy steel frame. The Pinata will also be a flame effect by having a flame hanging in the center of the pinata that burns at a constant steady rate. If money allows the flame effect concept will be enhanced with additional features. Attached to the base of the sculpture via chain will be a steel mallet with a rubber head to hit the pinata with. The pinata will ring or clank and jingle in a cacophony of sound. 

My project has been funded by Burning Flipside to the tune of $150.00. That money was granted due to an award for being the most absurd, yet environmentally friendly piece of art submitted for a grant at Burning Flipside. 

This award is named in the honor of Twitch. A local Austin burner that passed away last year and is still missed greatly in this community. In response to this award being granted to me, I, in respect and gratitude, would like to dedicate this piece to the memory of Twitch. 


For this project we will be asking for a total of $2000.00. The break down is as follows. 

$500.00 will go to the steel needed to fabricate the project. This sum might grow but I am willing to pay for any unexpected costs out of pocket.

$500.00 will go to the propane and electronics needed for the flame effect portion of this project. 

Also, we are asking for $1000.00 to cover transportation rental and fuel for a round trip from New Orleans to Austin. 

We will be offering some unique hand made perks for your donations including custom buttons and more!

If in the event we do not reach our goal we will try our very best to raise funds through other means to bring a finished sculpture to Burning Flipside.

Please help us by donating what you can to this project and sharing as much as you can. We only have 18 days to raise these funds and hope to meet our goal.

We hope to bring this project to Flipside and to other art festivals in the future. We also can't wait to let the community interact and laugh with us at this silly art project!!! 

Thank you! 

David

<3

story:
Charm specifications:

☆ 2.5" acrylic charms
☆ Clear epoxy
☆ Double sided printing
☆ Come with a rose gold star key ring clasp

☆ INITIAL GOAL — $300
The initial goal will be Deku, Bakugou and Todoroki at 300$

 

☆ STRETCH GOAL 1 — $500
The first stretch goal will fund Kirishima and Uraraka at 500$

 

☆ STRETCH GOAL 2 — 700$ 

TBA 

☆​ STRETCH GOAL 3 — 1000$

TBA

☆  Manufacturing — 60%
☆  Packaging — 20%
☆  Shipping — 10%
☆  Fees — 10%

☆ Campaign ( 1 month ) — from middle of September to middle of October
☆ Production ( 4 to 6 weeks ) — from middle of October to End of November
☆ Shipping ( 1 to 2 weeks ) — from End of November to middle of December

( just in time for the holidays~ )

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The charms you see here are photoshop mock-ups of what the actual product will look like.  Furthermore, colors may vary from one monitor to another so there might be slight variations in the design and color once the charms go into production. 

This is my first campaign ever so I'm hoping things run smoothly, but should any errors occur during manufacturing or shipping or other unforeseen problems which could cause a slight delay in the timeline, backers will be notified immediately. 

Thank you for all the support and understanding ♡ I hope we can launch a successful campaign together!!

story:
WeScreen Studio, a new project put together by River Takada of RIVTAK Handmade, to raise funds to purchase the MiScreen- a custom screen maker produced by RISO Japan.  The screen making machine will greatly streamline and provide inclusive tools for future students during creative workshops for all ages. 

  • For the past 7 years, River has taught kids and adults a variety of textile skills, including the skills in low-tech screen printing- sharing her love for creative expression and play.  River has found that there are many limitations based on time and ability when it comes to learning a new skill and achieving goals in a workshop.  Students are limited to using the screens and images River has prepped in advance, or hand cutting out their own designs via a stencil.  Stencil cutting is an art form in itself and is very challenging to kids and people with limited hand abilities.  For many years, River has wished to have a machine that could instantly creative custom screens so everyone could play and experiment for the maximum amount of time at a workshop.  Enter the MiScreen- a machine that can transfer a design straight from a computer screen to a mesh screen in moments and get anyone printing!
  • With your donation, you are investing in future community creativity!   With the funds from this campaign, we will have access to making original screens so each student can express themselves with their experimental prints!  Small businesses will have access to creating an affordable screen, bands will have access to create a screen to print their own merchandise and fund their future projects!  Couples and families can get creative together while planning their weddings, family reunions and birthday parties!  Expecting a big life change - like having a baby- Host a creative party with originally printed invitations, or print things as your party activity.  The creative possibilities are endless.
  • When we acquire the MiScreen, we will officially open the WE-screen service branch and adding it to the Rivtak.com website, as WeScreen Studio.  This will be a new service to encourage our students beyond a workshop or classroom and hope it will be inclusive and provide an affordable option for creating 2D art for personal or commercial use.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our minimum goal of $3200 is needed to purchase the MiScreen Machine made by RISO, along with the minimum amount of tools needed for small group workshops and the basic supplies to start testing/training and fulfilling perks. 
  • Our stretch goal of $5500 is needed to purchase all the additional tools required to ensure a productive workshop experience, like a designated workshop laptop for the MiScreen software, scanner, drying rack, and an equipment station/cart to transport everything to workshops, along with 6 months rent to our storage unit studio space, set up specially for this project to train and test the new machine and record video tutorials!
  • Immediate Perks include getting an exclusive coupon code to order your own original design made into a screen in our first year in operation!  As soon as we get the machine, we plan on making screens-to-order so you can print at home!  And since you donated, you'll get to order as many original made-to-order at a premium discount- depending on your donation tier.  Each perk also includes a special digital "thank you" and custom prints along with some surprises!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal, we hope to reach at least our bare minimum needed to invest in the RISO made MiScreen Machine, retailing at $2500.  Everything else on our supply list will be purchased over time with the funds we can save from selling made-to-order screens- which means it might take longer for us to set up a streamlined working space and provide workshops. 
  • If we surpass our stretch goal, You will be investing in our community further by allowing us to provided sponsored (by You!) workshops for communities who want art therapy and community building!  With funds raised beyond our stretch goal, we'll be able to pay for supplies and labor to take our MiScreen into schools and beyond to promote creative expression.
  • Please share with your community to ensure we meet our goal so we can hurry up and set up shop!

The Impact

  • Our hope is to bring the MiScreen machine into classrooms.  We will travel once it's safe, but until then, we plan to create instruction videos to show people how to best utilize the machine we will all be investing in.  We hope to inspire creativity, and support local creatives by offering an affordable option for making screens.  Screen printing can be used in so many different ways, from making a profit, to having a craft afternoon with friends and family.
  • River has taught at institutions and creative hubs like NC Museum of Art, Duke Create, The ArtsCenter of Carrboro, Freeman's Creative, NCSU Craft Center and the Scrap Exchange.
  • We hope to share the MiScreen resources and provide the complete seamless experince with all the equipment purchased from this fundraiser to make set up and transportation to workshops easier for future instructors.  Setting up for a creative workshop is very laborious with toting in all the things, in our stretch goal we have budgeted for a workshop station on wheels which will house all our basic supplies and tools need for each workshop!

Risks & Challenges

We're doing a 'flex' campaign. That means that it isn't an "all or nothing" situation. BUT, we still need money and community support and backing to get this project off the ground. $5500 is our place to start, get research and development going, and screens out the door.

If we don't reach our entire goal, we hope to reach at least our bare minimum needed to invest in the RISO made MiScreen Machine, retailing at $2500.  Everything else on our supply list will be purchased over time with the funds we can save from selling made-to-order screens- which means it might take longer for us to set up a streamlined working space and provide workshops. 

Thank you in advance for your support and for sharing our project with others!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please consider sharing this project with your creative friends and family.  We want teachers, artists, business owners, team leaders, non-profits, hospitals, schools and everyone to have access to affordable tools to play and experiment with design and 2D art!

  • Help us make some noise about the MiScreen campaign!  We want to see what you would print on or what original art you would put on your screen!
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools to get our project out there!
     

Itemized Budget list of MiScreen supplies to get started on fulfillment of perk rewards, testing/training and supplies for teaching workshops (see spreadsheet attached):

MiScreen Exposure Unit: $2,449.00

MiScreen Print Board x 5: $245.00

MiScreen Plastic Frame x 5: $175.00

Double Face Tape (1” x 36yds) x 3: $31.35

Plastic Squeegee (9” Wide)x 5:  $29.75

Plastic Spatulas: $3.95

120 Mesh Roll (13” x 40’):  $160.00

MiScreen Pre-Cut 120 Mesh Sheets (20ct):  $99.95

Minimum Goal:  $3,194.00

Stretch Goal Items:

Portable Drying Rack for Prints: $101.00

Windows 10 PC Laptop:  $250.00

Fulfillment for rewards - estimation of labor & postage: $300.00

Hand Held Scanner:  $75.00

Research and training space-Storage Unit Studio, 6 month cost: $1,080.00

Workshop Teaching Cart/Station:  $500.00

Stretch Goal: $5,500.00

Thank you again of your support and please consider donating to this community project!

story:
Short Summary

We need funds to get the design to the printer! 

If this campaign goes well and there is a high demand for these t-shirts we plan on working with local cat rescues so they can put their logo on the back of the shirt and use the t-shirt sales to help their rescue efforts! We will also sell the shirts in house at the Crooked Tail Cat Cafe. Just like everything else we do at the cafe - it's all about benefitting the cats!

story:
Every year, students from the Visual Merchandising Arts program at Sheridan College put on a year end show. This show displays the creative abilities of our amazing students, and allows us to network with the industry.

By helping us financially, we will be able to purchase all the necessary supplies in order to create the beautiful story we want to tell at Brand X8: Flora. The students will be fabricating large scale props, dressing mannequins in some stellar fashion, and showcasing what we do best. This show is pivotal to creating connections with the industry and jump starting our careers, so we would love to make it the best it can be with your help!

Your donations will help us pay for many things. Among these are the cost of the gallery space, food and drink for our guests, and most importantly - all of our fabrication supplies. You will be investing in our future and we are so thankful for that!

Visit our website for more info on this years show and our students: http://brandx8.sheridanc.on.ca/

Thank you so much for your support!

story:
“Our minds have never been exclusively in our heads, have they? But the worlds inside our minds are as extensive, multiple and varied as the environments that engender them. Come and explore them with me.” Professor Jennifer Årnstay

My alter ego, Jennifer Årnstay, Professor of Material and Analogical Eco-Cognition, visiting from an unspecified time and place, is on a humanitarian mission to peoples of this aerea (area/era) to give information about, and hope for, an affirmative bio-political future. Professor Årnstay allows me both to make fun of and to create a sweeping, authoritarian account of the mind through a series of performance lectures which trace the evolution and future of human cognition and consciousness.  Her rigorously historical model argues that radical changes in the environment have led and will lead to equally radical alterations in the human mind. A central thesis of her work is that  language that evolves as a solution to survival pressures in 200,000 BCE becomes an existential threat to humans by 2000 CE. She reveals that a new mind configuration, with multiple and non-linguistic consciousnesses, rooted in the deep history of humans in landscape, makes survival of the anthropocene (for humans and non-humans) possible. 

In parallel with the development of the Professor Årnstay performance lectures,  I have been collaborating with artists, designers and computer scientists to create and workshop participatory exercises designed to facilitate play with our everyday experience of the mind. (In  Professor Årnstay's terms, she and her team have developed a series of cognitive exercises that provide experiential, material and phenomenological experiences of the mind configurations she explores in the lectures.)  The cognitive exercises include:

  • The Bicameral Emulation Exercise (BEE) designed to speak separately to the two lobes of your brain, giving you a taste of life with a Bicameral Mind.
  • The Alter Ego Workshop (AEW)  that foregrounds the language-based and very malleable construction of "self."
  • The Davian Bead Game a visual meditation/turn based game with an alien intelligence, that allows you to reconnect with the deep visual and analogical centers of the mind.

Funding Needs

The IMPCON concept has been workshopped intensively before small audiences, now we are ready to broadcast Professor Årnstay's work as widely as possible.  We are developing her vital lecture and cognitive exercise material for presentation online at IMPCON.org.

We need funding for

  • Video Production (graphics, animation, editing)
  • Interactive online versions of the cognitive exercises (graphics, programming)
  • An Augmented Reality cognitive exercise (graphics, programming)

Funder Perks

Thank you perks for our funders include:

  • Iconic Professor Jennifer Årnstay Postcards - signed by Professor Årnstay!
  • Laminated pages of Professor Jennifer Årnstay's original IMPCON lecture notes! 
  • Pdf files of Professor Jennifer Årnstay's entire, stunning, IMPCON lecture.
  • Bicameral Emulation Exercise (BEE) Kits. The material elements for the BEE cognitive exercise that helps you (mentally) separate the right and left lobes of your brain.
  • Alter Ego Workshop Kits (AEW). The material elements for the AEW cognitive exercise that facilitates building and playing with Alter Egos.
  • The unique Dark Energy Headgear that Professor Jennifer Årnstay used to channel the Davi alien during early versions of the Davian Bead Game cognitive exercise.
  • The actual, original DRESS that Professor Jennifer Årnstay wore during shooting of the video lectures.

Impact

As a thought experiment that explores the possibility that language and narrative currently distort and limit our cognitive capacities IMPCON is designed to have impact on a variety of communities.  It stands as a creative intervention into conversations about:

  • the relationship between human consciousness and environmental disaster.
  • embodied, non-conscious and unconscious forms of "intelligence." A fundamental assumption of the project is that cognition is grounded, not abstract -- intelligence evolved tightly coupled to specific geo-spatial-physical needs.
  • feminist critiques of theories that equate human intelligence with language, men, and rationality.
  • the affective turn in the arts and cultural criticism that reflects disquiet with the domination of language/text in our knowledge production processes, but less often cops to the contradiction that many of us use language to make such critiques. IMPCON points at this problem: using story-telling with conscious paradox to make its arguments.
  • the importance of alternate thinking-spaces and methods from the arts that can add convention-breaking and radicalizing perspective to philosophical, scientific, and popular discourses on the mind.

Collaborators and Acknowledgements

I would like to thank all the people who have worked on Improvising Consciousness at different times including: Dave Pape (software, hardware, video, photography, ), Dorothea Braemer (video editing and consulting), Yvonne Fulmore (graphics and animation), William Sedig (graphics and animation), Devin Wilson (software, hardware, performance), Deb Burhans (software, robots), Neil Coletta (creative team, performance), Courtney Hatten (software, robots), Min Young Kim (creative team, software), Lisa van Wambeck (designer), Tyler Brown (performer), Isaac Johnson (performer), Vanessa Webb (performer), Lucy Anstey-Pape (performer). More Information here about some early IMPCON events.

I would also like to thank the funders who have got us this far: The Gender Institute, Digital Humanities Institute, Techne Institute for Arts and Emerging technologies, College of Arts and Sciences, and Department of Media Study all at the University at Buffalo.

Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute to IMPCON please help by visiting and sharing the website! IMPCON.org

“Do you ever feel you can’t put the true richness of your thoughts into words? Do you ever wake up and find the solution to a nagging problem is suddenly in your head? What is really going on in our minds: hiding in there behind language?” Professor Jennifer Årnstay

story:
About:

Through The Arctic Circle 2017 residency, I seek to keep making images that engage in an ongoing regional conversation that surrounds the growth and evolution of Maine’s relationship to the North Atlantic and the Arctic. Going forward, I must consider and expand my response to participate in a constantly evolving conversation and in congruence to other new contextual positions. For instance, how do initiatives for the economic development of Maine acknowledge and/or ignore Arctic issues while simultaneously leveraging changes in climate?

ICELANDx207
In 2013, the Icelandic shipping company, Eimskip, moved their North American headquarters to Portland, Maine. As an artist, the newly arrived royal blue shipping containers at the International Marine Terminal signified both the growing exchange of goods + services and a hidden cultural + human entanglement that needed to be observed, recorded and shared. In 2015, I received an individual artist project grant from the Maine Arts Commission that allowed me to participate in a nine-day artist residency aboard an Eimskip container ship from Portland, ME to Reykjavík and to discover those elements through a podcast and photography at the liminal space between exchange; at the intersection of art + commerce. This project lives as ICELANDx207 (website).

Going Back (to the sea), To Move Forward
The previous work I produced at sea focuses on Maine’s connection to Iceland via Eimskip’s Green Line shipping route and pays close to attention to the humanity found in shipping and at sea. Yet despite that thoughtful effort, the truth of the perspective I’ve provided remains undoubtedly rooted in issues more specific to exchange and commerce. It is but one half of an answer to a much larger question. 

In contrast, I imagine the traditional Tall Ship harkens back to a simpler time like reading a book instead of infinitely scrolling up. It’s with this sentiment of respect for natural beauty combined with the research and investigative efforts onboard that I can continue to address both integral components of the same coin.

For the new work produced during this residency, the mutually shared arena of the sea will act as the scientific control in presenting these intersecting yet polarizing concepts through similar but distinct viewpoints. I will experience the underlying source of our current conversations and bring that story’s voice to the table. I am confident it is here I will find the next images I need to make.

 

Your support is critical.
And thanks to Fractured Atlas, it's tax-deductible!

ARCTICx207 is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of ARCTICx207 must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

Here's the budget breakdown:

Residency Cost: $6300
Round Trip Airfare to Svalbard: ~$2500
Medium Format Film, Processing + Scanning: $1200
Extreme Cold Weather Clothing / Gear: $1500
Website / Hosting / Transcribing: $500

 

Why Maine? + Experience: 

From Maine and The Arctic:

Arctic change will have a direct impact on Maine’s economy, coastline, and natural resources. Until recently, Alaska has been the only U.S. state to have a voice in current Arctic affairs. In 2013, the Maine North Atlantic Development Office (MENADO) was formed as an initiative of the Maine International Trade Center to increase trade and investment between Maine and markets of the North Atlantic Region and to develop Maine’s policy in Arctic Affairs.

MENADO was awarded the opportunity to host the Arctic Council Senior Arctic Officials meetings in Portland (October 4-6, 2016).

At the beginning of 2016, I received a grant from SPACE Gallery’s Kindling Fund to support exhibiting ICELANDx207 in an Eimskip shipping container to be displayed in Congress Square Park in conjunction with the Arctic Council SAO arrival to Maine. 

 

The Arctic Circle Residency:

Artist and scientist led, The Arctic Circle is an annual expeditionary residency program. The Arctic Circle brings together international artists of all disciplines, scientists, architects, and educators who collectively explore remote and fascinating destinations aboard a specially outfitted sailing vessel.

The Arctic Circle provides a shared experience for its participants to engage in myriad issues relevant to our time and to develop professionally through interdisciplinary collaborations, exhibit opportunities, and public and classroom engagement.

The Arctic Circle program supports the creation and exhibition of new and pioneering work, and aims to empower the creative individual while fostering the collaborative.

In 2017, The Arctic Circle program embarks on two high Arctic expeditions aboard an ice-class expedition sailing vessel. International artists of all disciplines, architects, scientists and educators alike are invited to apply.

The Arctic Circle 2017 programming takes place in the international territory of Svalbard, a mountainous Arctic archipelago just 10 degrees from the North Pole. Each expedition provides the opportunity for artists and innovators to pursue their personal projects on board while exploring collaborations with the expedition’s fellow participants. Our vessel and home during our time in the remote Arctic, a traditionally rigged Barquentine, is equipped with workspace, common areas, and ample room for privacy and creativity.
story_txt:
About:
Through The Arctic Circle 2017 residency, I seek to keep making images that engage in an ongoing regional conversation that surrounds the growth and evolution of Maine’s relationship to the North Atlantic and the Arctic. Going forward, I must consider and expand my response to participate in a constantly evolving conversation and in congruence to other new contextual positions. For instance, how do initiatives for the economic development of Maine acknowledge and/or ignore Arctic issues while simultaneously leveraging changes in climate?
ICELANDx207In 2013, the Icelandic shipping company, Eimskip, moved their North American headquarters to Portland, Maine. As an artist, the newly arrived royal blue shipping containers at the International Marine Terminal signified both the growing exchange of goods + services and a hidden cultural + human entanglement that needed to be observed, recorded and shared. In 2015, I received an individual artist project grant from the Maine Arts Commission that allowed me to participate in a nine-day artist residency aboard an Eimskip container ship from Portland, ME to Reykjavík and to discover those elements through a podcast and photography at the liminal space between exchange; at the intersection of art + commerce. This project lives as ICELANDx207 (website).
Going Back (to the sea), To Move ForwardThe previous work I produced at sea focuses on Maine’s connection to Iceland via Eimskip’s Green Line shipping route and pays close to attention to the humanity found in shipping and at sea. Yet despite that thoughtful effort, the truth of the perspective I’ve provided remains undoubtedly rooted in issues more specific to exchange and commerce. It is but one half of an answer to a much larger question. 
In contrast, I imagine the traditional Tall Ship harkens back to a simpler time like reading a book instead of infinitely scrolling up. It’s with this sentiment of respect for natural beauty combined with the research and investigative efforts onboard that I can continue to address both integral components of the same coin.
For the new work produced during this residency, the mutually shared arena of the sea will act as the scientific control in presenting these intersecting yet polarizing concepts through similar but distinct viewpoints. I will experience the underlying source of our current conversations and bring that story’s voice to the table. I am confident it is here I will find the next images I need to make.

story:
Our Story

About four years ago I created an anonymous virtual artist named Bryn Oh with the intention of seeing whether a digital character could be accepted and succeed outside its virtual world and in the land of flesh and blood artists.  Would people scoff at the idea or would it capture their imagination?  Since that time Bryn's work has been shown at  Nuit Blanche, the World Expo in Shanghai (Madrid Pavilion), with IBM, in movies such as "My avatar and me" and in projects with people such as Cannes winning director Peter Greenaway (Big Bang) and artist Stelarc.   Bryn was also a  Web3D Conference presenter in Paris, France as well as profiled on RAI TV in Italy and Art21.  Bryn has had the good fortune to exhibit in various Universities worldwide and has also been added to the syllabus of others. Currently Bryn is the subject of three thesis works and has recently received a New Media grant from the Canadian government.     The government grant is to produce a 30 minute machinima (Bryn Oh is actually even mentioned in this wikipedia definition under 'sound in machinima') and to create an exhibit in a museum or gallery which would then incorporate Second Life.  In September, Bryn was written about in Vogue magazine (Italy) while also exhibiting Second Life artwork at a museum in Rome (Museo in Commune) . 

     I generally just create narratives that reflect on things in my  life and I have discovered that many people  share an empathy towards these works.  The success of Bryn has been very surprising and rewarding for me.


The Impact

     I am not going to pretend that I am changing the world, but I do truly believe that I am working in a new artistic medium or frontier.  It may be my fanciful imagination but perhaps one day Bryn and others could be written about in those same art history books I read while in art school.  I think all artists dream of being fortunate enough to stumble upon something new as it is happening.  There were the Cubists, Surrealists, Minimalists and hopefully one day there will be the Immersivists.  That is what I dream of when creating 3D environments.

     A painting is a static 2D slice of time but a virtual world can be a painting you enter and explore with few constraints.  It has duration, sound, movement, Interaction and is shared by hundreds of thousands from all over the world.  You chose where to go in the environment rather than follow a scripted camera.  In the video above it comes across as a movie, but in the actual space you can walk down the road or off into the snow.  You can explore buildings or look under a bed to find a hidden music box or note. You are not a passive observer but rather an active participant in a virtual artwork.  There are many believers in its potential as an art medium.


What We Need & What You Get

    The land I work on in the virtual world is strangely expensive, and up until recently I had a wonderful patron who supported me with the region (Immersiva) which was my studio.  As an artist I can not afford to pay for this.  It is $300 a month and just not something I can do.

     Recently I was awarded a grant by the Canadian government to pursue a project in the virtual world.  It involves using virtual reality headsets that a gallery or museum visitor would put on to explore my virtual world.  I have been formulating ideas to have wind fans or a spray triggered to release a scent in the air in order to help create a deeper immersion for the viewer.  So for example if you walked up to a lilac tree in my virtual environment it would trigger a subtle spray in the real life gallery that would release the scent of lilac.  Or if they were walking through a field of grass gently blowing in the wind, there would also be hidden fans to create a breeze for the visitor thus helping to create that elusive immersion.  My goal is to try to get the visitor to forget for a moment the real world and almost feel like they are in my virtual one.

     The loss of my virtual land Immersiva means that I have nowhere to build my grant project nor exhibit my large narrative builds for residents of the virtual world.  Right now I am applying to galleries to have my work shown, but they plan a year in advance.  So long story short, I need to get Immersiva back so that there will be a virtual space for gallery visitors to actually go to, and I need a space to work on large scale narratives.  

     What I need is tier payment for 18 months which would cover the exhibition obligations and provide a space to build and exhibit in.


Other Ways You Can Help

(Unleash the DIWO! -- 'Do It With Others' by asking folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign. Don't forget to remind them about the share tools!)

story:
About me:

For those who don’t know me, I am a freelance illustrator from Portland, Maine who enjoys working with many mediums, including pen and ink, chalk, crayon, and collage. Over time I've built a portfolio of portraits, editorial work, and a good amount of personal work where I've had the flexibility to work without any boundaries or restrictions. 

This freedom has allowed me to be more experimental, incorporating my love of old photographs and weathered papers and moth-eaten documents into my work. I've collected vintage stamps, books, photographs, letters, matchbooks, and more from flea markets all over Maine, and a lot of this stuff has made its way into my work.

Earlier this year I was shopping in a northern Maine flea market when I came across a photo album that was roughly eighty years old. Inside I found photos of Nansen, a massive wooden ski jump located in Berlin New Hampshire, the town where I was born. Something clicked. I decided I wanted to tell my story by using other people’s abandoned memories. What better way to do this than with a book; a visual journal combining the complicated uncertainty of the past with the disorder and energy of contemporary drawings. 

Over this past summer I’ve worked hard on creating meaningful personal work, much of which I haven't shown to anybody. After months of ardent work I started compiling and organizing this work. Then I got even more focused, and began laying it all out into a rough draft.  I slowly and carefully rearranged and edited this draft into Discarded: A Visual Journal, a refined, 144 page, full color art book that tells a compelling visual story.  At this point I knew I was ready to start my campaign.

I am so excited that this book is now ready to be sent to the printers. By contributing to this campaign you are helping me bring to life a project that I’ve passionately worked so hard on. My goal all along has been to publish this visual journal and I so grateful to anyone who helps me reach this goal. Here's a small taste of the book:

  Goal and Timetable:

The reason my goal is set at $4,644 is because that is how much it costs to print and ship 500 hardcover copies. All of the funds raised through this campaign will go directly towards the cost of printing this 144 page full color coffee table / art book. As with most things, the more copies I am able to order, the cheaper each individual book will cost. At 500 copies the per book cost goes down dramatically, which helps me keep the price of each individual book down as low as possible.

As far as crowdfunding goes, this project is very low risk for you, the backer, and here’s why: Although reaching my goal will help me print 500 copies of Discarded, I will print the number of copies I need even if I don’t fully reach the goal. This means that if you help me fund this campaign, you can be confident that you will receive a book (and other perks) even if the campaign is not fully funded. Keep in mind that whatever you can give to help will absolutely make a difference and will be much appreciated. 

Because the art for the book is all done, and the book is fully laid out and edited, the only big obstacle left is printing and shipping the books. This means that as soon as this campaign is done the book pdf will be sent to the printer. Once the books are printed they will be shipped to me, and I will be able to then ship them (and other perks) directly to all of you. The time in between the end of the campaign and when you receive your package in the mail will be as short as possible. Because I am not in control of the printing I cannot give an exact shipping date, but I can say that as soon as I get the books I will be on top of packaging them and shipping them out to my backers immediately,

Shipping Note: I am making this book available to anyone internationally. The shipping costs will vary depending on where you live. 

 

About the Perks:

I've varied the different levels of perks available so that anyone who is interested in helping can afford to do so. I am also incredibly thankful to anyone who shares this campaign with their friends and family via social media or email. By pre-ordering your copy of Discarded  at the $25 level you are saving 20% off of the post-campaign retail price, and your book will be signed and personalized. 

I have included options for campaign backers to get original drawings, original art from the book, multiple books at a discounted rate, limited edition prints, and even the option to commission a piece of original art. So if there is something specific that you would like me to personally illustrate for you this is your opportunity to make that happen. If you have any questions about this campaign that isn't answered on this page please message me and I will get back to you as soon as I possibly can. 

 

http://www.instagram.com/lewisrossignol/

http://www.lewisrossignolart.com

lewisrossignol@yahoo.com

story:
Embracing The Future: A BNHA Fanmade Tarot Deck 

Hello! The BNHA Tarot Mod Team are very excited to finally bring forth this wonderful tarot deck created by our extremely wonderful and patient contributors.

This project went through a lot of rough spots, and it's definitely been quite a ride, going through quite the game of hot potato before finally ending up with the current mod team. It was a lot of hard work and now nearly a year later, we finally have preorders open, so thank you for everyone's support and we hope you enjoy the beautiful tarot deck and wonderful merch pieces these amazing artists have lovingly made. 

Our Goal

The BNHA Tarot Project has 60+ contributors, 78 cards and over 20 merch pieces. As such to be able to print everything and fairly compensate all the artists and mods behind this project our goal is $10,000!

Goal Break Down

Now 10k sounds like a lot, and it definitely is, so here's why. We want to be able to compensate our contributors fairly with a full bundle so our calculation of the goal was made with that in mind! Taking that into account it would cost a total of $5,000 to be able to do this. 

  • $3,500 | Participant Compensation: This is the amount of money necessary to be able to give all contributors a free bundle as thanks for their amazing work!
  • $1,500 | Participant Shipping: Shipping can be pricey especially when it comes to heavier packages.

Now the other 5k goes into a contributor printing. How does that work? I basically calculated how much we would need to sell in order to be able to compensate our contributors.

  • $2,000 | Deck Printing: Due to M.O.Q's deck printing is at a solid price. 
  • $1000-$2000 | Merch Printing: Because it's very difficult to determine the total amount of merch that will be necessary this particular expense is not set in stone and will fluctuate depending on what bundles the customers prefer.
  • $1000 | Shipping expenses: We also have to take into account shipping expenses for our customers and because it depends on the number of purchases, this particular cost isn't set in stone but can fluctuate.

Risks & Challenges

Every project comes with its own risks and challenges. In the BNHA Tarot project, poses the risk of not being fully funded like most projects always pose. Additionally, while we will be doing our best to be as quick and efficient as possible, there always exists the risk of shipping delays due to any issues that may arise with the manufacturers, but rest assured we will keep everyone updated in everything!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please be sure to spread the word about this project and reblog our post on Tumblr and twitter if possible! Any signal boost goes a long way!
