story:
FIVE HOURS OF AUDIO COMEDY!

I'm making an audio comedy science fiction series and would really love your support. I'm looking for people who want to see Flashback happen and who want to hear the majority of the episodes NOW!

BACKSTORY

When I was persuaded to set up the patreon account nearly seven months ago it was because I was desperate to find the time to finish a project that has been "on the go" now for over four years. Actually, it all goes all the way back to something I did in 2000, when FLASHBACK started out as an experimental art video pilot. Originally conceived of by myself and video artist Michael Balser, the video pilot was directed by me and completely funded by both Michael and myself. Unfortunately at the time, viewers misinterpreted the collection of example scenes we'd filmed as an entire episode plot line, which of course, didn’t really make sense and, as it was so disjointed, professional interest in taking the project any further dwindled. However, years later many people constantly asked after the show, what had happened to it and was I ever thinking of trying to do something like it again? I guess it was because, even after the way things went, their imaginations for something like this had at least been fired up.

Over a decade later, I decided to bring the story and its characters back to life - but keep it as cheap as possible and so, the idea of an audio series was born. In the UK, where I now live, audio series on CD and download are really big business. People love them and there are a number of companies out there making audio content for the CD/download consumer or directly for the radio. So, I chose to embark on a journey to write ten new half hour episodes and, as a tribute to the spirit of what Michael and I started back then, I tried to include as much of Michael’s sense of humour in these new scripts as possible - we lost Michael in  2002, but he has never left my creative side. While many of the original actors from the pilot video returned to recreate their characters for audio, some were unable to do so because of other commitments, and a few characters were completely redeveloped to reflect what they were originally intended to be, should a longer series have resulted from the pilot. The large ensemble cast consists of Canadians JoAnne Garries, Tara Samuel, Elfriede Erzen, Patrick Conner, Ryan Kelly, Viv Moore, Randall Lanthier, and David Tomlinson. They, along with a fabulous guest cast, have been joined by British talent: the writer/director/actor Nigel Fairs and the incomparable, multi-talented Sarah Douglas - who is best known in the science fiction world as the wonderfully nasty Ursa in the Superman films, Queen Taramis in Conan the Destroyer and so much more.

So, that was in 2011. I was like a one-man production company. I had written the material, invested in recording equipment, travelled back to Canada to record the actors in their own homes, travelled back to Britain to record cast here, and then bought audio software and started on the edits. All the work was being undertaken by me, on my dime, in whatever spare time I had, and in my initial enthusiasm, I had managed to finish about two and a half episodes when news came to me of the very sad death of one of my lead actors and friend, Patrick Conner. The project languished as a result, mainly because I couldn't bring myself to hear his voice - so upbeat in the out-takes, so fun to be around in recording and so genuinely giving as an actor and human being. So nothing happened on Flashback for some time. It was starting to look like a mountain that I'd never be able to climb, and the longer I left it, the taller and taller it seemed to be getting.

So to the beginning of 2014, and after talking with my friend Elfriede, who is also in the series, I began once again to edit. Elfriede told me that it would be a huge gift to the world and the people who knew Patrick to hear him perform one last time, in a little gem they didn't even know he had worked on. I had to agree with her, and now listening to his voice fills me with happy memories. But I suddenly found that time to work on edits had become almost non-existent because I was spending all of my work days on other people's projects in order to pay the bills. But since I had already invested a lot of money of my own into the project and needed to see it through to completion, another friend of mine suggested I sign up with Patreon.com and through gaining "patrons" of the arts, I'd get a sort of small salary every month - for every episode that I put out. It sounded like a great idea to force me to edit and mix the episodes, to then get a little income from them that could start to recoup my, and another friend's financial investment, and in effect, start selling the project to the public. So I signed up to Patreon, then promptly spent nearly £150 on advertising on my Facebook Flashback page and my personal page, and the Flashback blog and anywhere else I could, to get people interested in parting with $9 US for the ENTIRE ten episode series, (in nine monthly installments of course).

THE DISAPPOINTMENT

I thought for sure people would sign up to support the project. I even offered the first episode completely free and not part of the monthly contribution. The handful of people that did sign up are, and have been extremely good to me, but I think I was very depressed by the overall poor response. Lots of people I didn't even know, from places like Russia, Mexico, Japan, Germany, the US and Poland constantly liked the paid-for Facebook ads, the Facebook page itself and the free episode download or other "free" downloads such as previews of upcoming eps, interviews or other behind-the-scenes items. Every new episode got more and more Facebook likes (I had over six hundred likes off one advert alone) and attention, but sadly no one new signed up to Patreon. It is a little disheartening to think that possibly they felt that contributing $1 US per month (which worked out to less than £0.60) for nine months was either too much of an effort, or out of their price range.

Surprisingly, a lot of the lovely actors who were in the series sent me sweet messages saying that they would gladly contribute, but I turned them down. That was not what I was after. Besides, I was hoping that by finishing the series, I'd be able to eventually send money THEIR way - they all worked on Flashback for the price of lattes and donuts, after all! I think too that I was very disappointed on behalf of my actors - the Facebook campaign provided a lot of links to the actors' webpages and Facebook profiles, and I was shocked to see not one of the actors' friends or contacts had actually signed up to hear them in this new project.

So, I started to wonder what the overall problem might be. One person said that people in North America aren't really interested in audio projects and since many of the actors are from Canada, North Americans wouldn't buy into it and potential UK supporters or those from other countries wouldn't understand or empathise with the accents. Another friend told me it was all in how I advertised and that I really should promote the low, low cost of the series - given how a five-hour long audio here in the UK would likely retail for £25 - £40 for downloads alone. It was all becoming more and more complicated for me when all I wanted was for it to become much simpler! And I found myself adhering to the deal I made my patrons on the patreon site - I promised to put out one episode a month and, even despite not having a lot of free time, I've managed to do just that. I'm now up to seven episodes online, and I'm pretty proud of that accomplishment. The mountain seems a little smaller now, but there are three really big installments to come - the dramatic ending to the whole series still left to edit, score and mix over the coming Christmas season.

THE INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGN

I have given thought to this Indiegogo campaign and felt that I should be honest with the emotional ups and downs I've experienced over the last few months with the Patreon campaign. I did start to wonder though - was the lack of response from people because the work isn't a tangible event like a play or screening, or a solid object, like a painting or a book, but something  internet-bound and practically virtual? Was that perhaps dissuading potential supporters?

This year alone I have responded to requests on-line through Facebook and email, to support no less than four artistic projects and one social campaign for funding. I have joined those campaigns because I believe in the people that have put them on. I believe in their artistic or political visions and even if I can't be there to see the show, the project, the festival, the film, whatever it is, I want to be able to, in some small part, help make it happen. That is sort of how I'm approaching this campaign too. I'm looking for people who want to see Flashback happen.

WHAT AM I LOOKING FOR?

Well, the big thing I was hearing from people in terms of donating support was that patreon didn't offer the chance to send in a one-time donation. That is the nature of the thing really. It relies upon people donating in exchange for content and perks, on a monthly basis. Also, some people didn't really want the audio series because they don't listen to drama on audio, but still wanted to support me. In the end they just didn't bother because of the way the site operates. I get that. So, I'm taking yet another friend's advice and offering up the project on Indiegogo - to raise that last bit of capital to help me... well, first to recoup some of the ever-increasing amount of money that has already been put out by me, and next to afford the up-coming licensing fees for original music tracks, web hosting fees, etc. Plus, I really would like to get the series pressed as a box set of CDs and pitch the whole thing to radio stations in Canada, the UK and elsewhere and all that takes cash to do it. I know this is my project and I know that I am ultimately responsible for it, but it is also my art and it involves a dozen more artists in the creative process who are all waiting for it to come out, for it to be finished, celebrated and enjoyed. I also think that in return for any help you choose to give, you will get something back, whether that is the first episode on download, or indeed the entire series. So really, you will be buying the material as it comes fresh off the presses, so to speak.

MY ULTIMATE GOAL IS TO FEEL THAT WE ARE SUPPORTED

The ultimate reason for this campaign is to ask for your financial support - for ANY support you feel you'd like to give, no matter how small or insignificant you might think that is. It all adds up and if enough people help out, then this campaign will be a success. The best thing about Indiegogo is that it does offer the "one-time" donation - in any currency and denomination. In return, you'll be helping me to ear-mark the time necessary to get this project done, but more importantly, you'll make me feel that this project is in fact, LOVED and RESPECTED and that is really, so incredibly important to me... to just know that the project is being looked after by a whole bunch of people out there who have faith in me and the art that I can produce. By your support, you will prove to me that THERE IS an audience out there for this, and not just the ten wonderful people on patreon who I've happened to guilt into signing up for nine months!

So, if you are still reading this, then you probably understand the motivation for this campaign and will forgive the blunt way I've decided to pitch it.
story_txt:
FIVE HOURS OF AUDIO COMEDY!I'm making an audio comedy science fiction series and would really love your support.  I'm looking for people who want to see Flashback happen and who want to hear the majority of the episodes NOW!BACKSTORYWhen I was persuaded to set up the patreon account nearly seven months ago it was because I was desperate to find the time to finish a project that has been "on the go" now for over four years. Actually, it all goes all the way back to something I did in 2000, when FLASHBACK started out as an experimental art video pilot. Originally conceived of by myself and video artist Michael Balser, the video pilot was directed by me and completely funded by both Michael and myself. Unfortunately at 
the time, viewers misinterpreted the collection of example scenes we'd filmed as an entire 
episode plot line, which of course, didn’t really make sense and, as it was 
so disjointed, professional interest in taking the project any further 
dwindled. However, years later many people constantly asked after the show, what had happened to it and was I ever thinking of trying to do something like it again? I guess it was because, even after the way things went, 
their imaginations for something like this had at least been fired up.Over
 a decade later, I decided to bring the story and its characters back to life - but keep it as cheap as possible and so, the idea of an audio series was born. In the UK, where I now live, audio series on CD and download are really big business. People love them and there are a number of companies out there making audio content for the CD/download consumer or directly for the radio. So, I 
chose to embark on a journey to write ten new half hour episodes and, as a tribute to the spirit of what Michael and I started back then, I tried to include
 as much of Michael’s sense of humour in these new scripts as possible - we lost Michael in  2002, but he has never left my creative side. 
While many of the original actors from the pilot video returned to recreate 
their characters for audio, some were unable to do so because of other 
commitments, and a few characters were completely redeveloped to reflect
 what they were originally intended to be, should a longer series have 
resulted from the pilot. The large ensemble cast consists of Canadians JoAnne Garries, Tara Samuel, Elfriede Erzen, Patrick Conner, Ryan Kelly, Viv Moore, Randall Lanthier, and David Tomlinson. They, along with a fabulous guest cast, have been joined by British talent: the writer/director/actor Nigel Fairs and the incomparable, multi-talented Sarah Douglas - who is best known in the science fiction world as the wonderfully nasty Ursa in the Superman films, Queen Taramis in Conan the Destroyer and so much more.So,
 that was in 2011. I was like a one-man production company. I had written the material, invested in recording equipment, travelled back to Canada to record the actors in their own homes, travelled back to Britain to record cast here, and then bought audio software and started on the edits. All the work was being undertaken by me, on my dime, in whatever spare time I had, and in my initial enthusiasm, I had managed to finish about two and a half episodes when news came to me of the very sad death of one of my lead actors and friend, Patrick Conner. The project languished as a result, mainly because I couldn't bring myself to hear his voice - so upbeat in the out-takes, so fun to be around in recording and so genuinely giving as an actor and human being. So nothing happened on Flashback for some time. It was starting to look like a mountain that I'd never be able to climb, and the longer I left it, the taller and taller it seemed to be getting.So to the beginning of 2014, and after talking with my friend Elfriede, who is also in the series, I began once again to edit. Elfriede told me that it would be a huge gift to the world and the people who knew Patrick to hear him perform one last time, in a little gem they didn't even know he had worked on. I had to agree with her, and now listening to his voice fills me with happy memories. But I suddenly found that time to work on edits had become almost non-existent because I was spending all of my work days on other people's projects in order to pay the bills. But since I had already invested a lot of money of my own into the project and needed to see it through to completion, another friend of mine suggested I sign up with Patreon.com and through gaining "patrons" of the arts, I'd get a sort of small salary every month - for every episode that I put out. It sounded like a great idea to force me to edit and mix the episodes, to then get a little income from them that could start to recoup my, and another friend's financial investment, and in effect, start selling the project to the public. So I signed up to Patreon, then promptly spent nearly £150 on advertising on my Facebook Flashback page and my personal page, and the Flashback blog and anywhere else I could, to get people interested in parting with $9 US for the ENTIRE ten episode series, (in nine monthly installments of course).THE DISAPPOINTMENTI thought for sure people would sign up to support the project. I even offered the first episode completely free and not part of the monthly contribution. The handful of people that did sign up are, and have been extremely good to me, but I think I was very depressed by the overall poor response. Lots of people I didn't even know, from places like Russia, Mexico, Japan, Germany, the US and Poland constantly liked the paid-for Facebook ads, the Facebook page itself and the free episode download or other "free" downloads such as previews of upcoming eps, interviews or other behind-the-scenes items. Every new episode got more and more Facebook likes (I had over six hundred likes off one advert alone) and attention, but sadly no one new signed up to Patreon. It is a little disheartening to think that possibly they felt that contributing $1 US per month (which worked out to less than £0.60) for nine months was either too much of an effort, or out of their price range. Surprisingly, a lot of the lovely actors who were in the series sent me sweet messages saying that they would gladly contribute, but I turned them down. That was not what I was after. Besides, I was hoping that by finishing the series, I'd be able to eventually send money THEIR way - they all worked on Flashback for the price of lattes and donuts, after all! I think too that I was very disappointed on behalf of my actors - the Facebook campaign provided a lot of links to the actors' webpages and Facebook profiles, and I was shocked to see not one of the actors' friends or contacts had actually signed up to hear them in this new project.So, I started to wonder what the overall problem might be. One person said that people in North America aren't really interested in audio projects and since many of the actors are from Canada, North Americans wouldn't buy into it and potential UK supporters or those from other countries wouldn't understand or empathise with the accents. Another friend told me it was all in how I advertised and that I really should promote the low, low cost of the series - given how a five-hour long audio here in the UK would likely retail for £25 - £40 for downloads alone. It was all becoming more and more complicated for me when all I wanted was for it to become much simpler! And I found myself adhering to the deal I made my patrons on the patreon site - I promised to put out one episode a month and, even despite not having a lot of free time, I've managed to do just that. I'm now up to seven episodes online, and I'm pretty proud of that accomplishment. The mountain seems a little smaller now, but there are three really big installments to come - the dramatic ending to the whole series still left to edit, score and mix over the coming Christmas season.THE INDIEGOGO CAMPAIGNI have given thought to this Indiegogo campaign and felt that I should be honest with the emotional ups and downs I've experienced over the last few months with the Patreon campaign. I did start to wonder though - was the lack of response from people because the work isn't a tangible event like a play or screening, or a solid object, like a painting or a book, but something  internet-bound and practically virtual? Was that perhaps dissuading potential supporters?This year alone I have responded to requests on-line through Facebook and email, to support no less than four artistic projects and one social campaign for funding. I have joined those campaigns because I believe in the people that have put them on. I believe in their artistic or political visions and even if I can't be there to see the show, the project, the festival, the film, whatever it is, I want to be able to, in some small part, help make it happen. That is sort of how I'm approaching this campaign too. I'm looking for people who want to see Flashback happen.WHAT AM I LOOKING FOR?Well, the big thing I was hearing from people in terms of donating support was that patreon didn't offer the chance to send in a one-time donation. That is the nature of the thing really. It relies upon people donating in exchange for content and perks, on a monthly basis. Also, some people didn't really want the audio series because they don't listen to drama on audio, but still wanted to support me. In the end they just didn't bother because of the way the site operates. I get that. So, I'm taking yet another friend's advice and offering up the project on Indiegogo - to raise that last bit of capital to help me... well, first to recoup some of the ever-increasing amount of money that has already been put out by me, and next to afford the up-coming licensing fees for original music tracks, web hosting fees, etc. Plus, I really would like to get the series pressed as a box set of CDs and pitch the whole thing to radio stations in Canada, the UK and elsewhere and all that takes cash to do it. I know this is my project and I know that I am ultimately responsible for it, but it is also my art and it involves a dozen more artists in the creative process who are all waiting for it to come out, for it to be finished, celebrated and enjoyed. I also think that in return for any help you choose to give, you will get something back, whether that is the first episode on download, or indeed the entire series. So really, you will be buying the material as it comes fresh off the presses, so to speak.MY ULTIMATE GOAL IS TO FEEL THAT WE ARE SUPPORTEDThe ultimate reason for this campaign is to ask for your financial support - for ANY support you feel you'd like to give, no matter how small or insignificant you might think that is. It all adds up and if enough people help out, then this campaign will be a success. The best thing about Indiegogo is that it does offer the "one-time" donation - in any currency and denomination. In return, you'll be helping me to ear-mark the time necessary to get this project done, but more importantly, you'll make me feel that this project is in fact, LOVED and RESPECTED and that is really, so incredibly important to me... to just know that the project is being looked after by a whole bunch of people out there who have faith in me and the art that I can produce. By your support, you will prove to me that THERE IS an audience out there for this, and not just the ten wonderful people on patreon who I've happened to guilt into signing up for nine months! So, if you are still reading this, then you probably understand the motivation for this campaign and will forgive the blunt way I've decided to pitch it.

story:
WE"RE DOING IT AGAIN!!

We had our first Draw-mania! last month and it was a fantastic success, so much so that we just have to offer another, and maybe keep it going on a monthly basis, at least through the summer.

 

What Is It?

The New York art scene has been aching for a new Draw-a-thon for quite a while now. You know, get a bunch of the best figurative (nude) models, a room full of artists armed with their favorite drawing materials, and this time, add a little spice to the mix: A great DJ, some amazing drink specials, and for a twist, intersperse the figure models with Downtown's newest and most cutting-edge comedians. It'll be a fantastic evening for artists and their friends! If you're an artist who's been trying to introduce friends to what you do, or you're looking for a unique first-date experience with someone daring and creative, this is the event for you! (OK-- some of your friends aren't as cool as you about the nude models...There's a separate bar area. Problem solved!)

For the latest info on the event, check out our website: www.draw-mania.com

The Impact

Besides being a great, offbeat party experience, this event is also a serious resource for figurative artists and at the same time a terrific way for people with little or no experience to jump into the pool in a fun, non-judgmental environment. Figurative art is very much a living tradition, but it's also one that doesn't always get the attenuation it deserves. It may be the single most relaxing and meditative of all art-activities, but it's also one of the most exciting and one that really develops a person's drawing skills and visual perception faster and stronger than anything else.

 

What We Need & What You Get

This maybe the most modest campaign on indiegogo! We're doing everything to keep the cost down, and in fact, for the price of a single session at a regular class with a single model, we offer an assortment of top models, music and other great entertainment in an uber-cool East Village location. Nearly all of the revenue from ticket sales goes to the expenses of running the event and paying the models. We've structured the event to be self-supporting, but a little seed money to cover setup and opeerating costs will help us get a running start. We're asking the lowest amount indiegogo allows! 

In exchange for your support, you get tickets at a discounted price (or honorable mention on our website if you're not able to attend), and at the higher level, a terrific t-shirt as well!!

  

Other Ways You Can Help

DRAW! If you do already, encourage others. If you, try it-- you'll love it. And don't be afraid to push your boundaries--that's where figure drawing comes in. Dare, to enjoy it and have fun with it. Scientists believe it can increase the efficiency of your brain and keep your mind sharp and young at any age. And come to a Draw-mania event!

story:
This is really happining!!!

I am in Toronto!!!!!!!

THANK YOU everyone for your support.

Please help me send out one last push before the end. Share, share, share, using the tools under the video. 

 Why do I want to go to the Harbourfront Centre?

A residency will offer me much needed time to experiment and research my “water works” series. Through the development of this work, I will create large installations and consequently a public art portfolio. Currently, I am working on an installation called “Portals of the Past” through which I replicate the void of keyholes by using cast glass.
Images of “women in waiting” are sandblasted on their surface. The mixture of the keyhole form and female body transforms the object into a form of “peep-hole,” in which the viewer is positioned as a secret voyeur of an unaware object of study. I am also interested in the rise and fall of industry in our world. The portals, (keyholes, windows, and doors) are reference to architecture. I am interested in sharing the beauty that is imbued in old architecture, as they are also ladies “in- waiting” of their inherrent future.

 I am looking towards this residency as THE ideal opportunity to launch my artistic career in a new direction, work on those ideas that have been at the tip of my fingers and to build a business that will sustain myself for the future. I am excited by the possibility for exchange of ideas with the numerous artists in the community in the Craft Department at Harbourfront Centre, Sheridan College and the Greater Toronto Area arts community.

 Furthermore, this opportunity will provide me with an international network and the opportunity to work alongside of other artists making a living and sustaining their futures as artists. I intend to exhibit the work produced during this period in national and international galleries and museums and am presenting lectures and workshops to the members of the art community in 2013, as well as to the wider public, upon the completion of my residency.     

Perks... Perks... Perks...


       

 Sun Catcher                         Glass Earrings

                                                                                                                    

What your awesome  contributions will cover.

Housing costs

Food

Travel Insurance

Liability Insurance

Clear Glass (to feed the furnace- she gets really hungry) aka supplies

Colored Glass                                                                Lace Vases

Glass Grinding Tools

UV Image Transfer Kit and Film for Sandblasting Glass

Transport

 

What is the Harbourfront Centre?

Harbourfront Centre, situated on Toronto's waterfront, is an innovative not-for-profit cultural organization that creates events and activities of excellence that enliven, educate and entertain a diverse public. Their mission is to nurture the growth of new cultural expression, stimulate Canadian and international interchange ("That's me! Their first American Woman in Glass.”) and provide a dynamic, accessible environment for the public to experience the marvels of the creative imagination. Their vision is to provide a vibrant home for the culture of our time, inspiring people through the magic of the creative spirit.

 

 The Craft Departmentat Harbourfront Centre is a dynamic axis point for contemporary expression Canada and an integral part of the country’s largest public multi-disciplinary arts complex.They inspire people to engage with the ideas being expressed by today’s craft designers and artists.

 

If you are ever in Toronto, you must come visit this place. Harbourfront Centre has so much to do; you will need at least a day to spend here on the Waterfront. AND make sure you wave to me in the glass studio. I will be the one with the big smile on my face because of YOU. Your generous donations are making it possible for me to take advantage of this incredible opportunity.

 

My friends… thank you for your continual encouragement and support!

  

Other ways that you can support this project? 

  • Share, share, share with your networks

  • like this page on your facebook

  • blog about it

  • become a promotions member of my team

Thank you!!!!!!!!!!

Nadine

 

www.nadinesaylor.com

 

 
 
 

                                       Thimble

                             The Art Lover

story:
Short Summary

I had a vision one night on the Playa last year after an encounter with several random groups. I had a 8 person art car and alot of people I taxied around said they could not get on the other big art cars. Well this kinda stinks because I had the same thing happen my first year on the Playa too. This vision involves a bus, tons of lumber, metal, welding, paint, and a all to make a LARGE CARGO area called a flight deck. NOT JUST DANCING and MUSIC EITHER I want to see maybe a fire conclave ride aboard one night doing shows then maybe one night be a slumber party with chill music, PJs and pillows all over the deck. Open your mind and give me input as to what is imaginable what is possible here. Hell I could even host the first plane landing on a carrier in the BRC ever. Well RC flying of course. Skydiver target area (maybe if someone arranged for it). The ideas are endless and with the communities help, and funding, it can be what YOU want it to be used for...like a bacon cook off at the trash fence on Friday at Sunset. But I SOOO want to just build it. What it is used for is up to the ones on the deck at the time.
Please help with the ideas, the donations, and the funds and we will see you in on the Playa 2013-)'(-

What We Need & What You Get

The bus has been obtained so we just need help with these materials and transport support to Black Rock City, North of Reno, NV.

We will use the funds to get the following elements for the build:

-8200--lumber and steel for framing and decking for the flight deck/Hull and Tower

-600--hardware for securing flight deck (bolts, screws,ect)

-6200--Fuel & tranport fees (trailered by big rig to Playa for safe&secure shipment/I don't have CDL needed for air brakes on highway)

-300--Insurance for transport (When traveling from the Playa to storage, it has to be street legal)

-1000--Storage in the off season (location will never be disclosed...sorry)

-1350--Maintaince (tires/annual oil changes/brake inspections/over all keep it safe in transit and on the Playa)

-2500--Lights and lighting elements

-3600--sound elements

-2000--safety equip(fire ext/safety lights/ALL STOP alarm system/Rear&side cameras/Crew radios/first aid stations)

The Impact

The greatest gift is a wonderful memory. I would build it for the people and have a bitching platform for 50+ people at a time to dance the night away in deep playa ops. NOT JUST DANCING and MUSIC EITHER I want to see maybe a fire conclave ride aboard one night doing shows then maybe one night be a slumber party with chill music, PJs and pillows all over the deck. Open your mind and give me input as to what is imaginable what is possible here. Hell I could even host the first plane landing on a carrier in the BRC ever. Well RC flying of course. Skydiver target area (maybe if someone arranged for it). The ideas are endless and with the communities help, and funding, it can be what YOU want it to be used for...like a bacon cook off at the trash fence on Friday at Sunset. But I SOOO want to just build it. What it is used for is up to the ones on the deck at the time.  No matter what the occupunts choose to do at any given monent will surely make a memory that could last a life time-)'(-

Other Ways You Can Help

We ar always looking for volunteers to help build, assemble on the Playa, drivers, spoters, bartenders, ect. Visit our facebook page for more infor and to volunteer for the SS Tittyhawk flight crew.
story_txt:
Short Summary
I had a vision one night on the Playa last year after an encounter with several random groups. I had a 8 person art car and alot of people I taxied around said they could not get on the other big art cars. Well this kinda stinks because I had the same thing happen my first year on the Playa too. This vision involves a bus, tons of lumber, metal, welding, paint, and a all to make a LARGE CARGO area called a flight deck. NOT JUST DANCING and MUSIC EITHER I want to see maybe a fire conclave ride aboard one night doing shows then maybe one night be a slumber party with chill music, PJs and pillows all over the deck. Open your mind and give me input as to what is imaginable what is possible here. Hell I could even host the first plane landing on a carrier in the BRC ever. Well RC flying of course. Skydiver target area (maybe if someone arranged for it). The ideas are endless and with the communities help, and funding, it can be what YOU want it to be used for...like a bacon cook off at the trash fence on Friday at Sunset. But I SOOO want to just build it. What it is used for is up to the ones on the deck at the time.Please help with the ideas, the donations, and the funds and we will see you in on the Playa 2013-)'(-


What We Need & What You Get
The bus has been obtained so we just need help with these materials and transport support to Black Rock City, North of Reno, NV.
We will use the funds to get the following elements for the build:
-8200--lumber and steel for framing and decking for the flight deck/Hull and Tower
-600--hardware for securing flight deck (bolts, screws,ect)
-6200--Fuel & tranport fees (trailered by big rig to Playa for safe&secure shipment/I don't have CDL needed for air brakes on highway)
-300--Insurance for transport (When traveling from the Playa to storage, it has to be street legal)
-1000--Storage in the off season (location will never be disclosed...sorry)
-1350--Maintaince (tires/annual oil changes/brake inspections/over all keep it safe in transit and on the Playa)
-2500--Lights and lighting elements
-3600--sound elements
-2000--safety equip(fire ext/safety lights/ALL STOP alarm system/Rear&side cameras/Crew radios/first aid stations)


The Impact
The greatest gift is a wonderful memory. I would build it for the people and have a bitching platform for 50+ people at a time to dance the night away in deep playa ops. NOT JUST DANCING and MUSIC EITHER I want to see maybe a fire conclave ride aboard one night doing shows then maybe one night be a slumber party with chill music, PJs and pillows all over the deck. Open your mind and give me input as to what is imaginable what is possible here. Hell I could even host the first plane landing on a carrier in the BRC ever. Well RC flying of course. Skydiver target area (maybe if someone arranged for it). The ideas are endless and with the communities help, and funding, it can be what YOU want it to be used for...like a bacon cook off at the trash fence on Friday at Sunset. But I SOOO want to just build it. What it is used for is up to the ones on the deck at the time.  No matter what the occupunts choose to do at any given monent will surely make a memory that could last a life time-)'(-


Other Ways You Can Help
We ar always looking for volunteers to help build, assemble on the Playa, drivers, spoters, bartenders, ect. Visit our facebook page for more infor and to volunteer for the SS Tittyhawk flight crew.

story:
HELLO INDIEGOGO!

I’m James. I make interactive art & contraptions rooted in the juxtaposition between nature, man & machine. So it’s no surprise that my latest interactive sculpture "Sessilanoid: A Sum of All Parts" is a cocktail of barnacles, stormtroopers and the aurora borealis. At 10 feet high x 40 feet long and featuring elaborate programmed color patterns, Sessilanoid premiered in Los Angeles at Gallery 825/LAAA.org. The positive attention it received made it eligible to participate in Art Basel 2013! Click on the image below to see the video:

WHAT IS ART BASEL?

To paraphrase wikipedia, Art Basel “marks the summer reunion of the international art world, hosted by the city of Basel, which has been a cultural capital for centuries. The artworks exhibited attract more than 60,000 artists, collectors, gallerists, museum directors, curators, and art enthusiasts.” I still have to pinch myself to believe that years of pursuing my artistic inclinations has brought this epic opportunity.

GETTING THERE

With this amazing opportunity comes great costs that I have yet to manifest. $6500.00 covers airfare, lodging and shipment of Sessilanoid, as well as components needed to control the lighting. If by chance I exceed my goal, the funds will be put into getting the sculpture back home, (yup, just focusing on getting it there right now) and getting it ready for Art Basel Miami, which it was also selected for!

OFFERINGS & CONTRIBUTIONS

Additionally (and/or alternatively) to financial contributions, there are many ways to help. A few are:

• Blogs & Social Networks: If this sculpture inspires you in any way, please spread the word!
• Friend me on facebook.com/artcontraptions or Follow me on twitter.com/artcontraptions and spark a conversation. I am excited to hear your thoughts and feedback regarding Sessilanoid.
• Know of any other social media networks I should get hip to? Let me know!   
• Lastly, just send some good thoughts, you can never have enough of them.

Please peruse the showcased perks and know that all of them include your name listed as a contributor at the exhibition, as well as my unwavering gratitude, love & appreciation. Also, should you be interested in receiving updates, please join our newsletter here.

IN CLOSING

My passion is creating artworks that evoke wonder. With your generosity, I will share this intention with a global audience and fulfill a lifelong dream.

Thank you for supporting this journey.

James.

story:
Our Mission

Omit Limitation’s Gallery & Creative Space is an initiative to contribute to the community through creating an experimental space for developing artists in the city of Toronto. The gallery & creative Space will allow creatives to express themselves, gain exposure, build community and bridge the gap between emerging and professional artists.

Curatorial Statement

Our curatorial goal is to provide an unique perspective on what’s going around the city of Toronto. Through content creating and event programming Omit Limitation strives to push the boundaries while maintaining a strong local presence. The gallery will be a multi-disciplinary art space that will play a role in seasoning artists and be considered a safe place for all walks of life. Omit Limitation's Gallery & Creative space will be an extension of the values we stand strongly behind and instrumental in building our movement around the city.

More About The Space

Our new space is located right at Dundas West and Bloor. An area known for its strong sense of community and it doesn't hurt to be a 30 second walk away from the subway station.

What We Need & What You Get

We’re looking to raise $3000 (CAD) it will go a long way to cover interior décor, costs of forthcoming exhibitions and overall help supplement a resourceful system that encourages the development of arts and culture in the community.

Funding will be going towards:

-  Studio + Installation ( Interior Design, Maintenance, Licensing )

-  Production (Materials )

-  Electrical

-  Construction removal

- Exhibit Programming

Rewards

Our experiences and community can not be created without the vibe that the people contribute to our shows. So we set up a list of rewards you can get for helping us achieve our goal.

$5 (CAD) - Your Name On Our Website

Your name on our website Omitlimitation.com as an O.L ambassador.

$10 (CAD)  - Social Media Shoutout

We want to recognize you. $10 (CAD) gets you a shoutout with a link to your website / organization on our various social media platforms ( Instagram, Twitter & Facebook ).

$20 (CAD) - Free Entry Into Our April Events

Along with being included on the O.L ambassador list this is your golden ticket into  any April exhibitions and various showcases happening in the space. Get ready to experience with us!

$30 (CAD) - Your Name On Our Gallery Wall

We have plans of collaborating with local artists to do some work on some of our walls and we want you to get in on the fun too! $30 (CAD) guarantees your name in the game.

$50 (CAD) - Exclusive Exhibition

As well with your name on our O.L Ambassador list a $50 (CAD) contribution will get you an exclusive experience for an art exhibit in the summer of 2016. It's an invite only occasion and the experience will be priceless. We're very excited about our backyard too.

$100 (CAD) - Limited Edition Print & Invite

$100 (CAD) will get you a designed and signed invite to our opening reception by all of the creatives apart of Omit Limitation. This will be signed by the various budding artists on our team which include photographers, musicians, artists, fashion designers,graphic designers, writers and more.

350 (CAD) - Artists One Week Exhibit 


This one is for the creatives looking to use the space. $350 (CAD) grants you a week for artists to showcase work in the new gallery space. Omit Limitation aims to provide an affordable space for creatives to utilize. Now is the perfect time to show work with the spring time right around the corner. This is an offer an artist looking to host a solo show can't refuse. 

The Impact

Omit Limitation has been consistently hosting exhibits, music showcases, networking parties and screenings monthly for the past two and half years while creating original content on our publication. Our events have consistently garnered an audience and our exhibits are nothing without the vibe of the people that attend, that's a major part to the experience. Obtaining our own space is the next step forward for our initiative to continue to cultivate, raise community and evoke a creative consciousness in our atmosphere. You can find out more about our various events on our Omit Limitation website here.

Risks & Challenges

Since starting Omit Limitation it has always been our goal to get a space. Creative talks in our local coffee shops could only suffice for so long. The brand is growing and we want to continue to challenge ourselves. Our team of creatives constantly seek ways to improve the brand on the soul reason that we wouldn't be Omit Limitation if we remained stagnant and we are aware of the growing pains.

Time Management & Financial Costs

The Gallery is slated to open for Mid April 2016. We have a lot of work to get done to get it up to shape.We have planned a rigorous schedule to effectively and efficiently check off tasks and are being mindful of the financial pressure that renovations can weigh. Your support will help us take the financial burden off our shoulders and allow us to create a space at a higher level for the community. 

Admitting these obstacles are a reality our team understands that anything worth having is worth the risks, It's just a part of the game when it comes to creating art. Building the gallery and creative space is a maturing process for all of us and we are excited to have a space that can enable other creatives to create within.

Other Ways You Can Help

We're looking to raise 3,000 (CAD) If you don't have the money to spare doesn't mean you can't help us make an impact. Help us spread the word by sharing this campaign using social media, indiegogo sharing tools, word of mouth anything helps to make the dream work.

Thank you for all your support!

story:
Help MudFire's Volunteers get to NCECA 2017

  • MudFire is an open access ceramic studio in Decatur GA. Our instructor base is comprised of volunteers working in exchange for 24/7 access to our studio. Most of our volunteers are post BFA or students needing access to wheels, kilns, clay and glazes. Daphne and I provide mentor-ship and guidance but we wanted to do more for this particularly motivated and special group of volunteers. We are personally donating artwork, time, and studio perks to this campaign to help these volunteers get to NCECA 2017 in Portland.
  • As artists ourselves, we know how cost prohibitive setting up a studio or traveling to a conference can be for less established artists. Crucial networking, residency and job opportunities, and show connections can be made during NCECA. Also, Portland's galleries and museums will participate, giving our volunteers the opportunity to see artists working in ceramics from around the world. Additionally, speakers, presenters, and demonstrators will be discussing their techniques for surface decoration, 3D printing for clay, ceramic printing technologies, and more! The chance to see and interact with those on the forefront of the makers movement and technology in ceramics will be invaluable to MudFire both in the experience of our volunteers and how new techniques will come back and be incorporated in our home studio.
  • Giving to this campaign will give these artists a chance to experience all that NCECA has to offer and in exchange they will give you an item handcrafted by them, here in our studio.

 

Help Fund and Get a Handcrafted Ceramic Item

  • Conference attendance costs an average of $300 per person, flights will be close to $400 per person, plus housing expenses of $300 per person. With a group this size covering these expenses will not be possible without help from others.
  • In exchange for your generous gift, MudFire's artists have created handmade objects ranging from pins, ornaments, and magnets to cups, mugs, robots, and vases. There is something here for everyone at every price range. MudFire will also be donating studio perks and Deanna and Daphne are personally making artworks as well.
  • If we don't reach our goal on Indiegogo - our volunteers are also participating in holiday shows and sales to self-fund the rest of their trip to NCECA. Any raised funds will be distributed and used toward our NCECA goal.

The Perks

Note to local Decatur/Atlanta purchasers - we had to include shipping to post but we will give you a credit for shipping (or you can let us know if you want the extra $ to be an extra donation).

Handmade Ornaments by Deanna Ranlett - $5 and $10. Deanna screen-prints on each porcelain ornament which are then high-fired in our gas kiln and strung with baker's twine. Squares and Stars - approx 2" are $5. Larger vintage shapes and ATL - $10.  Colors vary - please request if you have a preference. Deer and graphic patterns in all colors. Deanna also makes a special ATL ornament if you are interested in that she'd be happy to make you one!

 

Handmade Pins by Meredith Bradley - $10. Meredith has made adorable cacti and succulent pins with a variety of shapes and colors. She also crafted diamond pins in gray/white, pink, blue, and purple - faceted little beauties. Each comes with a metal pin back. Please request if you have a specific preference or would like more photos. We can communicate via email before sending your purchase.

 

Handmade Gear Magnet by Mike Klapthor - $10. Robot gear refrigerator magnets - what better to hold your artwork and photos on the fridge? Mike also has a variety of colors and we'll do what we can to accommodate any favorite color requests.

 

Handmade Stoneware Mug by Daphne Dail - $25. Beautiful, swirly, curvy white stoneware with a matte glaze fired here at MudFire in our gas kiln - fired with love by Daphne.

 

Handmade Raku Ring Holder by Dallas Ward - $25. Raku lover, Dallas Ward, will make, fire, and flame these crackle glazed ring holders perfect for all of your treasures.

 

Handmade Salt pinch bowl with salt by Shana Wood - $30. Shana Wood, MudFire member and friend makes these adorable little salt bowls - they look cute on the counter or on your table.  Beautiful Briny Sea has donated salt for your bowls as a bonus gift we'll include a bag of yummy flavored salt :) All bowls are blue, white, green but patterning will vary slightly.

 

Handmade Air-plant holder by Shana Wood - $30. Air plant hanger with plants from Shana Wood - shipped ready to hang. Shapes and Patterns vary slightly.

 

Handmade Whiskey Cup by Susie Yong - $25. Susie (Sueji) throws, scrapes, and carves these great little whiskey or juice cups - they feel great in your hand and each is shown a ton of love! Shapes and colors vary slightly.

 

Handmade Whiskey Cup by Clarice Allgood - $25. Clarice is offering an elegant whiskey or juice sipper in dark chocolate clay. These are ready and waiting to be shipped in time for Holiday gift giving.

 

Handmade Mug by Niki Patriarca - $50. Niki's fresh take on layering and color - these mugs are like a sweet garden fence - so great for morning coffee or tea.

 

Handmade Mug by Kaitlyn Chipps - $50. Kaitlyn is MudFire's tiny elf. She makes these gorgeous drippy, faceted mugs with whimsically elegant handles. These are a top seller in our gallery in Decatur and you'll fall in love. Choice of red clay or white clay available.

 

Handmade Robot Jar by Mike Klapthor - $75. Who doesn't want a robot with a secret storage compartment? Made with love here in our studio in Decatur - colors and shapes vary slightly.

 

Handmade Vase by Marisa Mahathey - $75. Sgraffito carved simple, classic lines with handiwork like a fine wedding cake - Marisa's unique style is clean and cool. Perfect gift for a winter wedding!

 

Deanna makes you a batch of cookies or your favorite cake - $50 - locals only on this one please - this item can't be shipped :) Those of you who have been in our studio know what Deanna likes to do second to her love of ceramics........BAKING!

 

Date Night at MudFire - $100 - Have a date night with you and a friend, partner, spouse, etc. We'll teach you how to throw on the wheel or hand-build (your choice)! We will schedule a time after your purchase and include all materials and firing. You will end up with 2-4 pieces each - fired here at MudFire. MudFire will donate 100% of the proceeds of your purchase.

 

Custom Set of Dishes by Deanna and Daphne - Plate, Dessert Plate, and Bowls for 6 people - $500. Daphne currently throws the pottery for Bellina Alimentari in Atlanta GA at Ponce City Market. Deanna is working on a project for IHG hotels. We will consult with you to provide a customized set of dinnerware for you and fire them onsite here at MudFire.

 

MudFire Trial Month - $99 - Come spend a month with us and fall in love with clay at our beautiful Decatur studio. MudFire will donate 100% of the proceeds of your purchase.

 

MudFire Year plus a gift of your choice from one of the artists above - $1500. Pick a gift from the list above and join us for a year! MudFire will donate 100% of the proceeds of your purchase.

 

The Real-Real

We need shoppers like you to make this possible. Your purchase will have a direct impact on the future careers of these artists. Ceramic art making is an important part of art and functional design with many restaurants and businesses making a return to American made and handmade goods. Appreciation for the handmade object is something special for our artists to experience and through your purchase you will be sharing that you also believe in the handmade object and find art-making to be a necessary part of life.

Our artists have already begun production on these objects and are excited at the prospect of this campaign. Many are ready to ship before the holiday season!

Ways to Help

If you can't help now, we will be having two Holiday Sale opportunities at MudFire. On November 26th, and December 3rd we will be opening our studio for our annual holiday sale featuring MudFire members and volunteers.

  • Please help us to share the campaign with friends and family who also appreciate the ceramic arts. Consider sharing this campaign on your social media platforms - we would all greatly appreciate it.

Thank you so much for your help and support!

Handmade Whiskey Cup by Clarice Allgood - $25. Clarice is offering an elegant whiskey or juice sipper in dark chocolate clay. These are ready and waiting to be shipped in time for Holiday gift giving.

 
Handmade Mug by Niki Patriarca - $50. Niki's fresh take on layering and color - these mugs are like a sweet garden fence - so great for morning coffee or tea.

 
Handmade Mug by Kaitlyn Chipps - $50. Kaitlyn is MudFire's tiny elf. She makes these gorgeous drippy, faceted mugs with whimsically elegant handles. These are a top seller in our gallery in Decatur and you'll fall in love. Choice of red clay or white clay available.

 
Handmade Robot Jar by Mike Klapthor - $75. Who doesn't want a robot with a secret storage compartment? Made with love here in our studio in Decatur - colors and shapes vary slightly.

 
Handmade Vase by Marisa Mahathey - $75. Sgraffito carved simple, classic lines with handiwork like a fine wedding cake - Marisa's unique style is clean and cool. Perfect gift for a winter wedding!

 
Deanna makes you a batch of cookies or your favorite cake - $50 - locals only on this one please - this item can't be shipped :) Those of you who have been in our studio know what Deanna likes to do second to her love of ceramics........BAKING!

 
Date Night at MudFire - $100 - Have a date night with you and a friend, partner, spouse, etc. We'll teach you how to throw on the wheel or hand-build (your choice)! We will schedule a time after your purchase and include all materials and firing. You will end up with 2-4 pieces each - fired here at MudFire. MudFire will donate 100% of the proceeds of your purchase.
 
Custom Set of Dishes by Deanna and Daphne - Plate, Dessert Plate, and Bowls for 6 people - $500. Daphne currently throws the pottery for Bellina Alimentari in Atlanta GA at Ponce City Market. Deanna is working on a project for IHG hotels. We will consult with you to provide a customized set of dinnerware for you and fire them onsite here at MudFire.

 
MudFire Trial Month - $99 - Come spend a month with us and fall in love with clay at our beautiful Decatur studio. MudFire will donate 100% of the proceeds of your purchase.

 
MudFire Year plus a gift of your choice from one of the artists above - $1500. Pick a gift from the list above and join us for a year! MudFire will donate 100% of the proceeds of your purchase.

 
The Real-Real
We need shoppers like you to make this possible. Your purchase will have a direct impact on the future careers of these artists. Ceramic art making is an important part of art and functional design with many restaurants and businesses making a return to American made and handmade goods. Appreciation for the handmade object is something special for our artists to experience and through your purchase you will be sharing that you also believe in the handmade object and find art-making to be a necessary part of life.
Our artists have already begun production on these objects and are excited at the prospect of this campaign. Many are ready to ship before the holiday season!
Ways to Help
If you can't help now, we will be having two Holiday Sale opportunities at MudFire. On November 26th, and December 3rd we will be opening our studio for our annual holiday sale featuring MudFire members and volunteers.
Please help us to share the campaign with friends and family who also appreciate the ceramic arts. Consider sharing this campaign on your social media platforms - we would all greatly appreciate it.
Thank you so much for your help and support!

story:
Yalla Studio 8 - #YallaStudio8

Who we are:

Studio 8

Studio 8 is an independent art and dance collective and we run our own community-based performing arts space in Amman, Jordan. It was founded by two brothers, Anas and Abdul Hadi Nahleh for their love of dance. There was nowhere for them to practice when they began because dance in Jordan is often limited to those who can pay for it, so they learned to dance in the street. The Nahleh brothers are now accomplished and renowned breakdancers, have been running their own studio for two years, and want to give the local community the space to create and practice that they didn’t have as young dancers.

It is our belief, and we have seen this proven over the years, that the performing arts give people an outlet for self-expression, self-discovery, and healing. They also encourage creative and critical thinking. Many of our students are youth who cannot otherwise afford arts and dance training, have no access to the arts at school or at home. We have students from all different walks of life, including refugees to Jordan from surrounding countries. What our students have in common is their talent and dedication.

Our mission is to maintain our studio as a safe space for new ideas and art forms out of reach from commercial, corporate and cultural constraints.

For the last two years we have:

Performed at street art events such as Big Fat Street Jam, Fire Jam, Baladk, and the launch of FADA317 graffiti space.

Provided unique and interesting dance classes such as West African Dance with drumming, Indian Dance, Dabkeh, Break Dance, Popping, Hip Hop, Belly Dance and Salsa.

Facilitated our very own Laughter Yoga sessions andpublic dance workshops in interesting locations such as Sakeyat Addarawesh cultural café, 7Hills Skatepark, Darat Al Funun and the streets of Amman.

Initiated the very first comprehensive circus practice in Amman, working with fire spinning, stilts, wheel spinning, and more.

Created “The Making Of” series of workshops which were hosted in Darat Al Funun and included creative writing, dance and poetry, dance drawing, dance and live music, dance and space, and digital storytelling. These were available free of charge to the general public.

Arranged the only Beatbox workshops available in Amman, whose participants go on to compete for the national King of the Beat and Beatbox Unlimited competitions. These competitions are often the first time these young artists have the opportunity to be on stage.

Produced an environmental and contemporary art exhibition in Amman city centre.


KEEP ART AND DANCE FREE BY MAKING A CONTRIBUTION NOW.

The Studio 8 Team:

Founders: Abdul Hadi Nahleh & Anas Nahleh  

Project and Space Coordinator: Abood Aladham

And Many Volunteers & Friends!

Why you should back this campaign?

We have worked hard these past two years to build a strong artistic and dancing community. Now we need your help. We can build an even better Studio 8 community if we have a place to ourselves because we will not be limited by noise complaints. At the moment, we are being evicted by our current landlord. This is our second eviction in two years. This is happening in spite of our honesty and up front approach when we sign our rent contracts with landlords and in spite of our efforts to select locations which are soundproofed and commercial areas. The only reason is the intolerance of art, music and dance. Your support will give us more flexibility when looking for an adequate and nice space. And most importantly, it will greatly contribute to the creative and artistic effervescence of Amman! 

We have big ideas for our space. We are not worried about students and attendance or activities. We are OVERFLOWING with ideas. We plan to hold big community dance classes for everyone! We want to host cultural events! We want to host events with film and food! We want a communion of ideas and dreams. We want artists to feel comfortable using the space as a collaborative hub and simply make amazing ART. It is our dream to host an artist residency to bring artists from all over the world and to give free community classes in Amman. With your help all of this is possible. You help us get our space together, and we’ll take care of the rest and bring you ART, DANCE and FUN!

Where your is money going

Although our classes and programmes are popular, the challenge we are currently facing is our landlord and neighborhood’s hostility to dance. We do not have the funds to get a new space right now, and we have been barred from hosting arts events in our current space. Your donations will give us that margin to find the right space for our community.

Break down of costs

Rent (for 1 year): 7000 JDs

Administrative needs: 2000 JD

Furnishings: 2000 JD

Installation of dance floor, mirrors, sound system: 1500 JDs

Renovation of the new space: 1000 JD

Campaign (fundraising drive and events): 1000 JDs

Total: 14,500 JD which is equivalent to approximately 20,000 US Dollars.

What are the risks involved?

Our greatest challenge is finding the best space for our activities. But never fear! We have our whole team working on finding the perfect location for Studio 8. This is our top priority now and we are deeply committed to using your donations wisely because we know that if we fail now, we lose everything and Studio 8 will close. 

How else can you help?

Every little bit helps. Donate to our campaign, share it and give us a big shout out! Like our pages on social media, hashtag your posts with #YallaStudio8 and if you are artists or dancers, tag us in your practice photos for a like, a retweet/regram or even a Facebook share. We want to hear from you. If you’re in Amman, Jordan at any point, come see the new space you funded! We make awesome tea and have exceptional conversation skills. We are not just pretty faces.

Jokes aside, every penny you donate counts not only towards our new space, but helps us make our community and art sustainable and free from corporate pressure. Most importantly, our struggling students will be the ones who truly benefit. Your donation will give them a place to practice, learn and thrive. So…yalla! Let’s go!

SCROLL DOWN FOR REWARDS 


What people are saying about Studio 8?

“When I first knew about Studio 8 I was very relieved that -finally- a collective of dedicated & professional artists are in Jordan, who fully understand and respect the concept of "Street Art", and who are developing a solid network of emerging & established street artists. I have worked with Studio 8 when I was managing Baladk Street Art Project with Al Balad Theater last May, & I was thrilled to deal with professional, punctual, passionate and creative artists who added an authentic feel to the project. Studio 8 should continue their rehearsals & workshops and should maintain their working spaces, because Jordan and Jordanian brilliant street artists deserve to be on the map of street art, and Studio 8 are the ones who can do that, develop it, and take it to an international level.”

Lubna Al Juqqa, Al Balad Theatre

"[Abdul Hadi and Anas'] primary goal was to support independent artists and alternative art projects locally, regionally and internationally, and open a place for community leaders and creative workers to collaborate and work together.
Young, talented Jordanian dancers themselves, the Nahleh brothers believe dancing is one of the best ways to express yourself and build a community with others. Their passion for dance has allowed the Studio 8 to thrive, to become a place that houses a variety of different dance workshops, ranging from hip-hop to breakdancing and contemporary dance, all at a small fee to the general public."

Sami Haven, Dar al Yamsine

"Although work is what initially brought me to Amman, it's the community, support and friends I made at Studio 8 that made me stay."

Nicola Houlihan, Researcher

On behalf of the Studio 8 Community

Thank you for supporting Studio 8! Support the performing arts in Jordan and share this with your friends so we can dance on!

#YallaStudio8

story:
About Manfred and Julia

Julia and Manfred are senior Arts Management majors. Both extremely passionate about self-confidence, diversity, and loving yourself, creating a magazine to promote self-love was the obvious choice for these artists.

While Julia uses fashion to express that one can be in love with themselves inside and out, Manfred is taking his love for diversity, social justice, and his passion for all aspects of art, to bring a unique twist to the traditional lifestyle magazine. 

What We Need & What You Get

Daily Moda will cost $1,000 to get up and running. 

We've already purchased our domain in order to run Daily Moda online.

Writing is a lot of work, and takes a special skill set, interest, and can be time-consuming. We'd love to compensate our writers in any way that we can, meaning we'd be using a small portion of all donations received to help out our hardworking writers.

About $400 will be allotted towards online ads, such as Facebook and Instagram ads, as well as ads on other websites and popular blogs with high traffic. This will help drive traffic to our site, and help get our message of diversity and self-love out there.    

If we are not able to reach our goal, the money will still be put to good use, printing a spring catalog being our first priority, and compensating writers being the next. 

The Impact

Confidence is something so many of us struggle with, or have struggled with, and Daily Moda wants people to feel that they are indeed beautiful in their own skin. Daily Moda wants its readers to know that there is beauty in being different, in being an artist, and in being exactly who you are.

Daily Moda also provides a creative outlet for people to be heard and appreciated, especially for those whose voices have not been heard as loudly as others. In a world filled with injustice, Daily Moda serves as a safe space and sanctuary for YOU. 

Risks & Challenges

Marketing a new fashion and lifestyle magazine is a great challenge. There is a lot of effort and time that goes into social media marketing, which will be our main form of communication for this online publication. Being a two-man band, our biggest challenge will be splitting up creating the magazine, running a business, and being marketers all at the same time. However, we are extremely confident that with your help, Daily Moda will succeed, and YOUR voices will be heard far and wide. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Manfred and Julia greatly appreciate all of your time and would be eternally thankful if you could share this page, follow us, and spread the word about Daily Moda and the campaign. The message we wish to send is not exclusive to us two; it's the same message of love and acceptance that we all want to spread. Please don't stress if you are unable to donate; there are other ways to contribute which are absolutely FREE! Simply staying engaged in our content by subscribing to dailymodamagazine.com, and following us on our social media, shows your support and gives your featured peers an audience. You can also contribute by letting your friends and family know what Daily Moda is all about!

And remember, we've only got 60 days in total to reach our goal, so let's make this happen!

story:
In line with the Green Philosophy, Ossession who is always investing in research, style and innovation with respect for the environment, presents the first and unique, made in Italy bowtie, that is fully biodegradable, and 100% natural.


This mean if you have the idea to bury your bowtie for enough time, when you will come back searching for it, you won't find anything else than a little stain that remember your old bowtie color.
We didn't made this product with the idea of send him under the soil... we suppose you will pack away in his box inside the closet, or inside drawer!
This experiment you can do by yourself, is made for give the opportunity to everyone to realize that we are so much serious about helping build a new green economy, based on Bio products, eco friendly, nature friendly and human respectuf!

Bioplastics material series are the result of constant research and development of best italian producers of thermoplastic compounds.
Brings together dedication to providing high-quality products with their commitment to safeguarding the environment.
Bioplastic Ossession Bowties are an environmentally friendly brand that respect all criteria on the scientifically recognised standards for the biodegradability of plastic products (EU13432/EN 14995 and US ASTM D6400 standards).

All this increase a significant contribution to reducing CO2 emissions and the greenhouse effect (Kyoto Protocol).

The process of biodegradability is defined as the degradation of plastic (in aerobic or anaerobic conditions) in carbon dioxide, water (or methane), mineral salts and biomass, or by microorganisms such as bacteria, fungus and seaweed.

and this is the degradation profle during time


Man Bowtie
Stop at the idea of traditional, aged, and overclassic clothing accessories!
This is the first fully tridimensional, computer designed bowtie, suitable for men, kids and women.


Kid Bowtie
Same project, same lines, same colors, but smaller size, is the Ossession Kid bowtie, suitable for kids starting from 3 months old to teenager.



Woman necklace

Bowties are not only a man's and kid's trendy accessory, but also a cool woman's necklace, that you can wear during parties,  shopping times, working times and each other situation.
It is a not age limited accessory that is able to make a woman feel free to express her own personality and originality.
It can be the present for your daughter, your girlfriend, even for your grandma!


 

 We have plenty of colors  in mind. 
We love  fresh, young look and bright colors and you can match these on Mary Yellow, Peter Green, Andrew Red, Marlin Blue bowties, kid bowties or necklaces.

But you also need more serious colors for your business winter meeting,  your gala dinner and may be you prefer wear Laguna Seca Sky, David Blue,  Robin Green bowties, kid bowties, necklaces.

Do you plan to marry? Do you will attend some friend wedding? Do you have a special day and want to be elegant but cool, classic but refined, chic and awesome?
Well wear a Papa white or Joe Black Ossession bowtie!

People who had the chance to see and touch with hand our first prototypes used these words as description:
Ossession bowties and necklaces are NICE
Ossession bowties and necklaces are AWESOME
Ossession bowties and necklaces are GREAT
Ossession bowties and necklaces are FASHIONABLE
Ossession bowties and necklaces are FANTASTIC
Ossession bowties and necklaces are AMAZING




• 2015 Genuary - The idea started


• 2015 February - We met the right person and company that can provide us BIO                                          Materials, full biodegradable.


• 2015 February       - The first 3d prototypes

• 2015 March       - The first 3d printed prototype

• 2015 March       - Rubber mold for small production is ready

• 2015 April       - The first pre-production sampling is ready

• 2015 April       - Ossession matt boxes are ready



Risks & Challenges

If we don’t reach our fundraising goals, we’ll still begin the production, even withouth metal mold, even not so much colors. It will take longer, but we believe in this project!

This was a great idea that got us really excited to be a pioneer in using bioplastics on fashion products. 

With your support, we can move forward and begin something great together and inspire other business to take similar steps.

Wich are the products?
Ossession is proud to give you 3 different kind of products: Ossession bowtie, Ossession Kid Bowtie, Ossession Necklace.

Can I pledge different products?
At the end of campaign we will send you by mail a survay in wich you can choose the different colors and products you want to receive. Both if you pledge for a single Ossession and also for a COMBO or a FULL SET.


Wich are the size of the products?
Ossession Bowtie is around 10x5 cm.
Ossession Kid Bowtie is 7.5x5 cm.
Ossession Necklace is 7.5x5 cm. plus the  necklace around 80cm

Bowties are not only a man's and kid's trendy accessory, but also a cool woman's necklace, that you can wear during parties,  shopping times, working times and each other situation.It is a not age limited accessory that is able to make a woman feel free to express her own personality and originality.It can be the present for your daughter, your girlfriend, even for your grandma!




 

 We have plenty of colors  in mind. 
We love  fresh, young look and bright colors and you can match these on Mary Yellow, Peter Green, Andrew Red, Marlin Blue bowties, kid bowties or necklaces.


But you also need more serious colors for your business winter meeting,  your gala dinner and may be you prefer wear Laguna Seca Sky, David Blue,  Robin Green bowties, kid bowties, necklaces.
Do you plan to marry? Do you will attend some friend wedding? Do you have a special day and want to be elegant but cool, classic but refined, chic and awesome?Well wear a Papa white or Joe Black Ossession bowtie!




People who had the chance to see and touch with hand our first prototypes used these words as description:Ossession bowties and necklaces are NICEOssession bowties and necklaces are AWESOMEOssession bowties and necklaces are GREATOssession bowties and necklaces are FASHIONABLEOssession bowties and necklaces are FANTASTICOssession bowties and necklaces are AMAZING









• 2015 Genuary - The idea started
• 2015 February - We met the right person and company that can provide us BIO                                          Materials, full biodegradable.



• 2015 February       - The first 3d prototypes

• 2015 March       - The first 3d printed prototype



• 2015 March       - Rubber mold for small production is ready

• 2015 April       - The first pre-production sampling is ready

• 2015 April       - Ossession matt boxes are ready










Risks & Challenges
If we don’t reach our fundraising goals, we’ll still begin the production, even withouth metal mold, even not so much colors. It will take longer, but we believe in this project!
This was a great idea that got us really excited to be a pioneer in using bioplastics on fashion products. 
With your support, we can move forward and begin something great together and inspire other business to take similar steps.Wich are the products?Ossession is proud to give you 3 different kind of products: Ossession bowtie, Ossession Kid Bowtie, Ossession Necklace.
Can I pledge different products?At the end of campaign we will send you by mail a survay in wich you can choose the different colors and products you want to receive. Both if you pledge for a single Ossession and also for a COMBO or a FULL SET.
Wich are the size of the products?Ossession Bowtie is around 10x5 cm.Ossession Kid Bowtie is 7.5x5 cm.Ossession Necklace is 7.5x5 cm. plus the  necklace around 80cm

story:
While I'm an accomplished writer, editor, reviewer, creative educator, part-time musician, burlesque dancer, and aspiring actress (www.facebook.com/AliciaColewriter), there's an area these gifts can't help me overcome: my learning disability.

I have a mathematics disability which affects my spatial awareness. In short, unless I'm working conceptually large-scale or very abstracted, I can't create fine artwork. My life and soul are focused on creativity and I really need to create visually to sustain my personal happiness.

With the funds raised, I plan to begin the first of three classes at Spruill Arts Center in welding and metal work. I'm inspired to create work based on a transitory/seemingly unstable concept - the lotus rising from the mud on a "fragile" stalk, abstracted.

In exchange? My creative gifts! I have personal mini-essays to offer expounding on any artistic/philosophical/spiritual concept or conceptualization you'd like me to explore; I have original poetry; I have abstracted quantum physics artwork based on my understanding of a triple wave conceptualization of the universe and our place within such a conceptualization; we can even have a tea in the park and get inspired together!

What will be using the funding for? 

Classes - $400 each

Art supplies and shipping - $300

I will ask anyone who purchases mini-essays, poetry or artwork about collecting the works for publication in the future.  When I publish, you'll be given credit in the book or chapbook!

Q&A

What about framing and shipping?

Since many people I know are working artists, I promise to work out the most affordable framing and shipping situation with you.  You can choose to frame yourself or go for an affordable option I'll provide.  I'll follow your shipping preferences.

Do you actually know how to ship artwork?

Why, yes!  I was the Gallery Manager of Ad Hoc Art in Bushwick, Brooklyn, for a year, and shipped street art and screen printed works locally and internationally.  If something arrives dinged, now as then, I'll replace with no charge to you.  

Where have you exhibited?

My visual works have been shown at: Ballroom Studios, Atlanta (printed poetry); The Refrigerator Show, Atlanta (the same); Proximity Gallery, Philadelphia (featured in The City Paper); and Mint Gallery, Atlanta (Postcard Pinup show and Spirit Animal Exhibit).

Where have you been published?

You can find my poetry on Tor.com, Abyss & Apex, Ideomancer, Lakeside Circus, Mythic Delirium, Strange Horizons, Futuredaze Anthology, and Asimov's, among other publications.
